HEADLINE: Diminished Eminence In a Changed Domain

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
NOT long ago, in the blocks along Mulberry Street, the people who were fighting this city's plan to displace them for a gigantic ''urban village'' of new condominium buildings had reason to be dispirited. Urban redevelopment was hot, the city wanted a center-of-gravity downtown for a new, affluent population, and they were in the way.
 In June, the United States Supreme Court upheld a similar plan in Connecticut, all but inviting cities everywhere to use their powers of eminent domain to upgrade by turning over less-than-stylish neighborhoods to private developers.
And then, in a wave of unintended consequences, the climate brightened for the Newark property owners who went to court 10 months ago to contest the city's designation of their neighborhood as an ''area in need of redevelopment.''
 The Supreme Court decision had no legal effect on their case, but it did galvanize opposition. Property owners around the nation have benefited ''from the blowback to that decision,'' said Harold Simon, the director of the National Housing Institute, based in Montclair. 
 The Newark owners may be among them, especially since they portray theirs as the classic case that several justices expressed reluctance about: elected officials uprooting people at the bidding of politically connected developers. 
 ''It woke people up,'' George Mytrowitz, the owner of an auto body shop and a spokesman for the Newark plaintiffs, said of the Supreme Court decision, Kelo v. City of New London. And in New Jersey, Mr. Mytrowitz said, ''judges are the ones now that got woken up.'' 
 Indeed, while New Jersey courts have long deferred to local governments' plans for redevelopment, a Superior Court judge in Essex County rejected a downtown renewal project in Bloomfield in July. On Oct. 6, a judge in Bergen County struck down a plan to raze two trailer parks in Lodi.
 ''We're on a roll here,'' said John H. Buonocore Jr., the lawyer for the Newark property owners, ''setting these things aside, coincidentally or not, after Kelo.'' 
 For good measure, the gubernatorial candidates, Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester, have criticized the Supreme Court ruling. In a radio debate on Tuesday, both said emphatically that they would curtail the use of eminent domain in New Jersey. 
 The Newark plaintiffs, calling themselves the Mulberry Street Coalition, represent about 20 of the 65 property owners in the redevelopment area, Mr. Mytrowitz said. They argue that their neighborhood was targeted almost three years ago not because it was blighted but because it was about to take off. Immediately to the north is the site of the new downtown sports arena. Along its western edge is the Ironbound, brimming with new, increasingly expensive two-and three-family houses. On Mulberry Street, several new bars and restaurants had opened, and the houses and small apartment buildings on the side streets were all occupied. But about half the area is made up of parking lots serving the downtown courthouses and post office, giving the neighborhood a deserted air after dark.
 In early 2003, the new plan for the Mulberry Street corridor materialized, drawn up at the city's request by the Newark Redevelopment Corporation, a local builder, and Metro Homes, a larger builder in Hoboken. It carved out eight blocks for mid-rise buildings with 2,000 condominiums, shops and restaurants. 
 The City Council voted in May 2003 not to continue with the plan. But last November, after the developers contributed thousands of dollars to council members, the plaintiffs say, the council declared the 13-acre tract a redevelopment area. The developers have offered residents and businesses bonuses of $20,000 in addition to fair market value -- though that value will probably be disputed -- and relocation costs. To thwart holdouts, if necessary, the city may use eminent domain. 
 That is the troublesome part, said the area's city councilman, Augusto Amador. ''It's a moral issue,'' Mr. Amador said. ''I'm not against the project itself. But from a moral standpoint, I'm not ready to allow anyone to come in and take the property for private economic development.'' 
 While the Kelo decision made clear that such takings are not unconstitutional, whether Newark complied with the state's redevelopment law is another issue. For one thing, Mr. Buonocore said, ''an area in need of redevelopment'' should be designated before the city seeks a developer. ''They were announcing the development before they even asked the planning board to study the area,'' he said. ''They have no shame in Newark.'' 
 The law also requires the city to show that the area is ''stagnant'' or ''not fully productive,'' a conclusion that Mr. Buonocore says the owners can refute. The city contends that the preponderance of parking lots illustrates that the land is by definition underproductive. 
 Finally, as Judge Richard J. Donohue wrote in the Lodi decision, under the redevelopment law, eminent domain ''should only be exercised when private efforts are not likely to correct or ameliorate'' the blight. 
 Pat Smith, a spokesman for the developers, said that was exactly the case around Mulberry Street. ''There's been no significant initiative by the private sector in this area for 40 years,'' Mr. Smith said. ''So why should one believe that this is going to happen now? That's why government gets involved in areas like this.'' 
 The principals in the Newark Redevelopment Corporation, Emilio Farina and Bruce Wishnia, were building two-and three-family houses on nearby vacant lots in the Mulberry corridor when the city asked them for a more ambitious plan for the blocks closer to downtown. Their first houses sold for about $300,000, and by the time the city established the redevelopment zone, similar houses were selling for $400,000 to $500,000, Mr. Smith said. But if property values were rising, he said, it was because ''by investing in a neighborhood where no one else had invested, these guys created value.'' Mr. Buonocore said a simple rezoning would allow high-density development around existing houses and businesses. ''The market would have rushed in,'' he said. ''They always get greedy. They said, 'Let's make this a huge area and tie it all up.''' Mr. Buonocore said that as the city recently settled with owners in the arena site, a client of his there sold for $110 a square foot, the equivalent of $4 million an acre. 
 The plaintiffs hope to present similar evidence to Superior Court Judge Patricia Costello, who, coincidentally, was the judge who decided the Bloomfield case. In that decision, Judge Costello said the township had not demonstrated that the downtown area it had condemned was in fact blighted. And Judge Costello cited Justice Anthony Kennedy's opinion in the Kelo case, which, while supporting the use of eminent domain in New London, said that ''impermissible favoritism'' in deals with private developers is sometimes ''so acute'' that the condemnation should be barred. 
 In the meantime, the Mulberry Street case, like most, is a race against the market: the developers rushing to secure property before the coming gentrification drives up prices while the sellers seek delay for the same reason. 
 The property owners may benefit, too, from what Councilman Amador called ''the changing political climate.'' The councilman's ally, Cory Booker, will oppose Mayor Sharpe James or his chosen successor in the mayoral primary in May, and if Mulberry Street is still fighting then, Mr. Amador said, ''you may see a reversal.''

HEADLINE: Looking to Beat the Price of Heating

BYLINE: By GREG CLARKIN

 BODY:
THE calls for the chimney cleaners began coming into Total Chimney Care in July, about four months earlier than usual. 
 Then came the onslaught of phone calls for wood stoves, a pickup in business so sharp that Total Chimney, in Milford, added a second service truck and work crew to keep up. But even that hasn't satisfied the demand from customers eager to heat their homes with wood as a way to avoid higher prices for oil and natural gas this winter.
''We're booking three weeks in advance now,'' double the usual week and a half, said Laurie Paladino, the office manager. ''We're getting slammed.'' 
 With winter around the corner, consumers are nervous about heating costs. Having already watched gasoline rise quickly, then keep on rising, they realize that oil and natural gas could do the same, meaning they could be paying hundreds of dollars more to heat their homes.
 Even the price of wood is going up. The federal Department of Energy estimated that heating bills could be 30 percent higher this season.
 Actually, the price for home heating oil is already almost 50 percent higher, at $2.60 a gallon, up from $1.70 last year, oil dealers said. The Department of Energy said it expected natural gas prices to rise almost 40 percent, to an average of $19.67 per thousand cubic feet, up from $14.21 last winter.
 ''It's a unique year,'' said Sal Camera owner of Alpine Heating and Cooling in East Haven. ''Customers are talking about turning the thermostat down and putting on a sweatshirt. I haven't heard that in years.'' 
 There are about 682,000 heating oil customers in Connecticut, according to the Independent Connecticut Petroleum Association. They use 545 million gallons of heating oil annually, with each customer averaging 800 gallons a year. At that average and at the current prices, heating bills could increase to about $2,100, up from about $1,350 last year.
 But while the price for oil is higher, there appears to be a sufficient supply for the Northeast this winter, said Eugene Guilford, Jr., executive director of the association.
 ''If we have a normal or average heating season, we're in pretty good shape,'' Mr. Guilford said. There is an inventory of 14 million barrels in the Northeast, about 4 million barrels more than last year, he said. 
 Most dealers said they sensed a fear from customers who have seen how fast oil prices can rise and a realization that heating oil costing under $2 a gallon may be a thing of the past. They are reporting a sharp increase in calls from customers looking to lock in prices and upgrade to more-fuel-efficient heating systems.
 Peter Aziz, president of Bantam Fuel in Bantam, said the talk of higher energy costs is everywhere.
 ''People see it at the pumps, they hear it on the news,'' he said, and that has helped push some into action, including scrapping old, inefficient systems.
 John Irwin of Litchfield replaced a decades-old heating system in the house that he and his wife, Marion, own. He said the furnace was patched up last year to get through the winter, but a desire to save money and do their part to conserve energy pushed them to spend $5,000 on a new system earlier this year.
 ''There's a squeeze on our nation and this is our part,'' Mr. Irwin said.
 Mr. Camera at Alpine Heating and Cooling was also doing a big business replacing old heating systems, in some cases very old.
 ''Our installation sales are up 35 percent,'' he said. ''We're replacing units that go back to the 20's and 30's, believe it or not.''
 Many dealers have a variety of payment programs, including locking in a set price for the oil. But with the sharp price swings this year, some dealers discouraged their customers from signing contracts that locked in the current prices, which some dealers said may go down.
 ''There was tremendous interest in them, but we didn't like the volatility,'' said Steve Lombardi, who with his wife, Lynda, run Brodeur's Oil Service in Moosup. ''The volatility is such that it can change several times in an hour, and I've seen it change 20 cents in a day.''
 The inability of some people to pay their energy bills is something that concerns everyone from oil dealers to Connecticut officials.
 Claudette Beaulieu, deputy commissioner of programs at the Department of Social Services, said there has been an increase in the number of calls from people who said they will need help paying their fuel bills.
 And for some, making the call seeking aid is not something that comes easily.
 ''Certain segments of the population are reluctant to ask for help, but I think this year they're getting scared,'' Ms. Beaulieu said.
 With natural gas one of the leading ways of heating in many urban areas, some utilities are bracing for the impact of higher prices.
 The number of calls to Yankee Gas asking about budget billing programs has jumped, said Sandy St. Pierre, a spokeswoman.
 ''There's a lot of concern over what's going to happen this heating season,'' Ms. St. Pierre said. ''Everything is higher, and energy is taking a bigger bite out of people's budgets.''
 That is likely to translate into a larger than usual number of customers with bills past due, she said.
 Yankee serves about 194,000 customers, and from 55,000 to 65,000 are typically 30 days past due on their gas bill, she said. ''There will likely be more people who we expect will either be delinquent, have a harder time paying their bill, or be unable to pay,'' Ms. St. Pierre said.
 As a result, Yankee will work with the customers to help them pay their bills. ''We're constantly working to get customers in some type of payment arrangement,'' she said.
 Jeff Blodgett, vice president for research with the Connecticut Economic Resource Center, a nonprofit company that promotes Connecticut as a business location, said of the higher fuel bills: ''This really acts as a broad-based regressive tax. If you're earning $100,000 to $150,000, it's a minor inconvenience. But for families trying to get by on incomes of $30,000 to $70,000, high heating costs are a serious concern. In that area, with a couple of kids and a couple of cars, you're stretched pretty thin.''
 Which is why everybody from chimney cleaners to oil dealers to woodcutters can expect to be busy in the coming weeks. Ms. Paladino at Total Chimney Care said the price for a cord of wood was around $135 last year at this time, but has risen to $170 to $200 and is going higher because demand has increased.
 ''I'll bet you it will be $250 by December,'' she said. ''It's just supply and demand.''

 To save money and energy, John Irwin of Litchfield replaced his furnace with a $5,000 heating system. And old-fashioned fuel helps, too. (Photographs by Carl David LaBianca for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Long Branch, No Olive Branches

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH 

 BODY:
DAVID BARRY, the president of the Applied Companies, had just finished his presentation on a proposal to build an upscale residential and commercial project in this shore city. For the next phase of the redevelopment to continue, the town must condemn about four dozen neat, small homes on streets leading to the beach.
 On a recent day, brightly colored artists' renderings were arrayed on easels across the front of the Town Council chambers, contrasting with the stony faces of the council members as they braced for the public's turn to talk.
 Among the speakers was Bill Nordahl, a retired electronics company employee, whose apartment in a beachfront bungalow is in the path of the proposed redevelopment. He is a leader in the nearly two-year battle over the plans. 
 ''What David Barry didn't mention is that he is president of Applied now because his father, Joe Barry, is in jail for bribing people,'' said Mr. Nordahl, referring to the elder Barry's sentencing in 2004 to 25 months in prison for making $115,000 in payoffs to Robert C. Janiszewski, the former Hudson County executive. ''It is very clear that these people have too much power because they have so much money to throw around, and they are allowed to throw it around.''
 In Long Branch, there is no evidence or even a hint of illegal payments to anybody. But in the brave new world of redevelopment there is no tactic that is too extreme. Charging corruption or worse is all in the course of the war. ''They will use any attack they can,'' Mr. Barry said in an interview, ''and I have to sit there and listen to it.'' 
 Since a United States Supreme Court ruling in June -- known as Kelo v. New London -- emboldened municipalities to condemn property under eminent domain laws to make way for private development, anti-development groups have felt at once energized yet under siege, their avenues of legal recourse uncertain. 
 So in places like Long Branch, where the battle to block Applied's project was already emotion-drenched, the gloves have come off as anti-development groups try to block projects before the issue reaches the courts. 
 At the same time, many homeowners are looking to Trenton for the means to block redevelopment and the use of eminent domain. Legislation is pending to tighten the rules under which eminent domain can be invoked, and lawmakers as well as Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey have been asked to impose a moratorium on all redevelopment efforts relying on the use of eminent domain. 
 Local groups like those in Long Branch have held rallies and flooded state officials with letters and telephone calls in support of their cause. Yet those efforts do not have the support of local officials, especially those in distressed beachfront towns like Long Branch, Neptune and Asbury Park as well as in such urban centers as Newark, Camden and Jersey City. 
 William Dressel, the executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, says localities depend on growth.
 ''Given the fiscal condition of our state with its budget deficit and the absence of any lifeline whatsoever from the federal government, towns have been encouraged to work with the private sector ever since the redevelopment law in the state was passed in 1949 and amended in 1992 and 2003,'' Mr. Dressel said. : ''Where do people think development comes from? Some development fairy who waves her magic wand?''
 Rather, local officials are working hand in hand with developers, who say they already face prohibitive economic and political restrictions and do not need more limits on building from the State Legislature. 
 Mr. Barry of Applied criticized homeowners, like those in Long Branch, who try to block redevelopment projects, describing them as ''opportunists looking for higher prices for their property or the limelight and the very few who are really victims.''
 Political oddsmakers say that Governor Codey is unlikely to back a moratorium, although the two men currently running for governor have criticized the Supreme Court ruling and have said that they would curtail the use of eminent domain in New Jersey.
 Against this backdrop, State Senator Diane B. Allen, Republican of Burlington, and State Senator Nia H. Gill, Democrat of Montclair, are pushing a bill they introduced this summer to address what they consider inequities in the eminent domain laws.
 While the bill does not try to limit eminent domain, it calls for greater public involvement in the process. It increases the requirement for public hearings on condemnations and redevelopment plans, and narrows the definition of blight that could subject properties and whole areas to condemnation. 
 ''The bill would make the process for condemnation more transparent,'' Ms. Allen said. ''The bottom line is that the Supreme Court decision has jeopardized the security of many homeowners, and we should all be afraid.''
 Ms. Gill said that although she and Ms. Allen were trying to use widespread grass-roots concern about eminent domain to cajole developers into making compromises, ''it won't be a cakewalk.''
 There is already a great deal of resistance. Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, who also represents his city in the State Senate, said that the bill appeared to be ''a non-starter.'' 
 As Mr. James put it, the measure ''handicaps mayors and developers'' alike by undermining existing expectations about just compensation and limiting their ability to determine what is for the greater good.
 But Joseph Maraziti, a former chairman of the New Jersey Planning Commission whose law firm represents several towns on redevelopment issues, said some of the proposed changes may be inevitable, although they may now seem like heresy to developers and local officials.
 ''All of the forces are stacked against the developers now, so some modest upside for property and homeowners may be called for,'' Mr. Maraziti said. ''In the end, it is the future success or failure of these kinds of projects that matters the most to what we do.''
 If any eminent domain legislation is eventually passed, it may be too late for Mr. Nordahl and his neighbors along Ocean Terrace in Long Branch. These days, they scamper nervously from expanded bungalow to converted Cape Cod to see who in their neighborhood has already received the formal condemnation letters from the town. Once a letter arrives, a homeowner has 14 days to file a legal challenge. 
 In the last week, only 14 among about 40 property owners on the treeless, sun-baked blocks just west of the beachfront had received such notices. But they can see the signs of change outside their windows: just to the south, four- and five-story buildings with condominiums selling for $400,000 and up are under construction and advancing northward, as relentless as the ocean surf.
 One of the Ocean Terrace homeowners, Rose LaRosa, and her daughter Joanne are less worried about compensation than the memories accumulated in their house. Sitting at the kitchen table, they recalled how Rose LaRosa's father bought the house sight unseen in 1944. 
 Mrs. LaRosa's children and her children's children have grown up vacationing in that house, where she now lives year-round and where time was marked by when the fountain in the yard was built or the hydrangeas were planted.
 ''They say this area is blighted,'' Joanne LaRosa said incredulously. ''Does it look blighted to you? If anything, the town is trying to make it blighted because for the past decade they have denied permits and many of us have sought to make improvements.''
 The redevelopment plan seeks to replace the homes with 185 condominiums in three buildings, a community pavilion, a parkand a beachfront restaurant with windows jutting toward the ocean like the prow of a ship. 
 Mr. Nordahl likened the town's development plan to the Trojan horse. At first it appeared to residents as colorful maps in which their homes were in an area color-coded for in-fill housing, meaning only compatible new homes would be built on existing vacant lots and new sidewalks and lighting would be added.
 ''The in-fill areas were color-coded green, while the new construction areas were taupe, I think,'' he said. ''We thought we were O.K., and as recently as a year ago, planners in town were still telling us we were still an in-fill area.'' 
 But the plan approved by the Town Council earlier this month would raze every house in the neighborhood. 
 To Joanne LaRosa the proposed development is an insult to family and memory, and an aesthetic blow as well. The neighborhood is an organic, almost whimsical collection of houses that have evolved over the years with second stories, additions and other embellishments -- strikingly unlike the cookie-cutter condominiums moving north.
 ''It's getting like Disney World, an unreal, make-believe place,'' she said.

 In Long Branch, the gloves have come off as residents in the Ocean Terrace neighborhood battle plans for redevelopment. (Photographs by Jack Howard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sonata for Chromelodeon

BYLINE: By MICHELLE FALKENSTEIN

DATELINE: UPPER MONTCLAIR 

 BODY:
IN a large, bright room on the lowest level of Alexander Kasser Theater here at Montclair State University, Dean Drummond picks up two mallets that resemble giant Q-tips. He bangs on four massive wooden planks that rest atop resonators. The instrument, a marimba eroica, generates low, deep sounds.
 Never heard of a marimba eroica? There is good reason: It is one of nearly 30 instruments, all of which reside at Montclair State, that were invented and built by the composer Harry Partch from 1930 to 1974, the year of his death. The self-taught Partch, who worked well outside the music mainstream, built his instruments -- the bloboy, chromelodeon, eucal blossom, quadrangularis reversum and zymo-xyl, to name a few -- from materials as unusual as the names he gave them. Those include airplane fuel-tank nose cones, honey-colored gourds, brass shell casings, Chinese rice bowls and specially tuned light bulbs. Some look like musical instruments, others like sculptures. 
Partch's creations are tuned to a 43-tone scale, as opposed to the 12-tone scale used in most Western music. ''It's about gradations,'' said Mr. Drummond, a disciple and former assistant of Partch's who picked up his mentor's predilection for originality. Mr. Drummond, a music professor at Montclair State, also writes microtonal music and has invented his own instruments, which he calls the zoomoozophone and justrokerods.
 On Friday at 7:30 p.m. in Kasser Theater, Mr. Drummond's ensemble, Newband, will perform the New Jersey premiere of his 1996 composition ''The Last Laugh,'' a score for the 1924 F.W. Murnau silent film of the same name. The work is played on Partch, Drummond and traditional instruments.
 The trove of Partch instruments came to the school in 1999 with Mr. Drummond, who was made their caretaker in 1990 by the Harry Partch Foundation in San Diego. He credits the former chairwoman of Montclair's music department, Ruth Rendleman, for giving the instruments a stable home. Because of economic hardship and academic politics, the instruments, many of which are large and incorporate fragile elements like empty liquor bottles and tree boughs, had endured five homes in their nine years under Mr. Drummond's stewardship. ''The instruments take up space,'' Mr. Drummond said, ''and they don't consistently generate income.''
 Partch's compositions, including ''Ulysses Departs From the Edge of the World,'' ''Eleven Intrusions,'' and ''And on the Seventh Day Petals Fell on Petaluma,'' sound somewhat Asian and usually include parts for voices. Many of the instruments require a certain level of physical fitness to play, and Partch included stage directions for musicians as well. ''He wanted them to be actors, dancers and movers, too,'' said Danlee Mitchell, a professor of music at San Diego State University and head of the Harry Partch Foundation. ''You had to be a quadruple-threat performer. The physical look of a performance was just as important as the abstract music.''
 Partch was born in Oakland, Calif., in 1901 and moved with his parents to the Southwest. As a teenager he played piano in brothels and accompanied silent films. After a year of college, he dropped out and rode the rails as a hobo during the Depression. Several of his works refer to the time he spent tramping, including ''The Letter'' and ''Barstow.'' Partch is also known for the book ''Genesis of a Music: An Account of a Creative Work, Its Roots and Its Fulfillments,'' which was first issued in 1947 and enlarged for a 1974 edition. Partch had a stroke and died in 1974.
 Mr. Drummond described Partch as a bitter, alcoholic curmudgeon who also happened to be a genius. ''I loved him, so I put up with it,'' Mr. Drummond said. ''I was selfish, and he was the most interesting and brilliant person I had ever met in my life.''
 Students at Montclair State can study Partch's music, theories and instruments, as well as play in the Harry Partch Ensemble that Mr. Drummond directs.
 Mr. Drummond said teaching Partch's microtonal music to students increases their understanding of 12-tone music as well. ''I can't teach my students a second language,'' he said, ''without teaching them more about their first language.''

HEADLINE: Fading Foliage

BYLINE: By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
FALL arrives in Connecticut like a prom queen, draped in boastful reds, yellows and rusty browns, perfumed with wood smoke. It saunters through the Litchfield hills, then turns to the suburbs and cities, where one tree on one block can inspire an entire neighborhood's devotion.
 Fall is important here not only for the spectacle it creates, but also for the tourist economy it supports and the cultural symbol it represents; no season is more strongly identified with New England than fall. As far back as 150 years ago, Henry David Thoreau realized how special it was.
''October is the month of painted leaves,'' Thoreau wrote in his 1862 essay ''Autumnal Tints.'' ''Their rich glow now flashes round the world.'' 
 But what if the glow wasn't so rich?
 That is a question some scientists have already begun to ask, and they don't think it is hypothetical. Already this year, throughout New England, the foliage has been late and, some say, unspectacular. Scientists at the University of New Hampshire project that shifts in the climate caused by global warming will progressively dull the leaves throughout southern New England over the next century. Maples will move north and the remaining oaks and hickories will change colors later and with less verve, they say. If the projections are correct, leaf-peepers may be forced as far north as Canada for their fix of foliage.
 Indeed, one scientist says autumn in Connecticut has already lost its brilliance.
 ''We haven't had a really great display in the last 10 years,'' said Barrett Rock, a professor in natural resources and a researcher at the Complex Systems Research Center at the University of New Hampshire who has studied the effects of global warming on the local autumn landscape.
 This year, the problem has been intense heat in late summer and early fall, which delayed the changing of the leaves and may dull them, said Chris James, director of air planning at the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection. The average temperature in August was 73 degrees, nearly 4 degrees higher than the average since 1895, and the second-highest August average in that period, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The heat did not let up in September, when it was 3.7 degrees warmer than average. Precipitation was about one inch below average. 
 But global warming is a gradual phenomenon, and one warm year does not mean that fall will be this warm every year. Indeed, this year's reduced rainfall appears to be an anomaly; trends in precipitation show the state becoming wetter in recent years, and computer models, set forth in a federally financed 2001 report, the New England Regional Assessment, project that that trend will continue.
 Nonetheless, scientists like Dr. Rock say there is ample reason to worry. In the regional assessment report, Dr. Rock and fellow researchers at the University of New Hampshire and other universities in the region found that Connecticut's average temperature had increased by 1.4 degrees throughout the last century. The scientists used two different models to project what New England would look like over the next 100 years.
 Both models, Dr. Rock said in a telephone interview, are considered ''middle of the road,'' predicting gradual but not extreme warming trends. But both project that global warming will accelerate dramatically in New England. One forecasts an overall temperature increase of 6 degrees by 2090. That would leave Boston looking and feeling like Richmond, Va. The other model projected a climate like Atlanta's, a full 10 degrees warmer than Boston's.
 This year, a University of New Hampshire environmental scientist, Cameron P. Wake, issued a report in conjunction with Clean Air Cool Planet, a nonprofit group that studies climate change in the Northeast. Using different methods from the earlier study, the new report confirmed the warming trend in the Northeast throughout the 20th century, and showed it increasing over the last 30 years. The new report did not focus on foliage but found other significant effects to plants and trees, including progressively later bloom dates for lilac trees.
 The warming trends affect foliage in various ways, Dr. Rock said. As greenhouse gases accumulate and the earth warms, summer weather will linger into fall. That will delay the frosts that degrade chlorophyll and trigger leaves to change. It takes at least one frost in which temperatures fall to 30 degrees Fahrenheit or below to start the changes in the leaves. If those fall frosts are delayed, or the chlorophyll breaks down more gradually, leaf-peepers will not see the vibrant reds they have come to expect in Connecticut, Dr. Rock said.
 Last week, Marian Travis was decorating a lamp post near her house in Ossining, N.Y., with colorful fake leaves when she realized that something felt wrong though she was getting her neighborhood ready for fall, it felt more like summer. ''It didn't even fell like fall,'' she said. ''It is fall by the calendar, so you have to put the decorations up.''
 Ms. Travis said she thinks fall has changed since she was a girl. ''I remember in the fall, I'd walk home from school and there were so many leaves in the street and the gutter,'' she said. ''They don't have them anymore. I don't think the fall is like what we used to have way back.''
 Global warming will affect which tree species can survive in the state and which will move north to cooler climates, scientists say. 
 Maples, with their stunning red, yellow and orange leaves, are New England's treasures in the fall. Thoreau positively gushed over them, writing that they seem to absorb ''all the sunny warmth of the season.''
 Connecticut is full of maples, but changes in temperature, air quality and rainfall, the 2001 climate report said, will change the mix of trees in state forests. Connecticut officials said they have already noticed this trend. ''Already we see a lot of the maple trees moving northward,'' said Gina McCarthy, the commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection. ''The species is migrating northward.''
 Birches and beeches, two other species known for their foliage, can also be expected to migrate north, according to the 2001 report. 
 In their place, Ms. McCarthy said, leaf enthusiasts can expect to see more oak and hickory in Connecticut's 1.9 million acres of forests. Leaves from those two species are more muted in the fall, often turning brown or dull green.
 The 2001 report details other possible effects of global warming on foliage, including increases in plant diseases and insect outbreaks. Warming also increases ground-level ozone, which can damage leaves.
 But it is not just scientists who are concerned about the changing autumn landscape. The colors of fall are big business for the tourism industry. If the prom queen leaves town, and is replaced by a quiet unassuming friend in brown or dull green, will anyone come to see her? If the scientists' projections come true over the next century, will people seeking truly great foliage go all the way to Canada?
 Not so fast, said Connecticut tourism industry executives. 
 ''The general trend toward global warming is slow and almost imperceptible,'' said Jennifer Aniskovich, executive director of the Connecticut Commission on Culture and Tourism. Ms. Aniskovich said the state has had some of its most spectacular displays in the last two years. 
 Others were more adamant.
 ''Global warming has not in any way, shape or form come to this part of the country yet,'' said Pauline Simring, the owner of Pauline's Place, an antique and estate jewelry shop in Kent. ''If I was in Alaska, I would be concerned, but I am in beautiful northwest Connecticut. We willall be long dead if there is ever a change in this part of the country.''
 Janet Serra, director of the Northwest Connecticut Convention and Visitors Bureau, said people always seem to doubt the foliage. Nonetheless, the display in Litchfield County is consistently extraordinary, she said. Although she acknowledged that it is late this year, she still has hope for a beautiful fall.
 ''Somehow, mother nature always comes through,'' Ms. Serra said.
 Three million to four million tourists come to Connecticut in the fall, which is close to 40 percent of the state's tourism, Ms. Aniskovich said. Early bookings this year are about the same as last year, she said. 
 Businesses throughout the state depend on the foliage to draw tourists to the area.
 ''We've always marketed fall foliage,'' said Marianne Vandenburgh, who owns the House on the Hill Bed and Breakfast in Waterbury. Ms. Vandenburgh said she looks forward every year to the leaves on the beech tree in her yard turning copper. So far this year, she said last week, the tree has not changed color.
 ''The beech isn't changing,'' she said. ''The maples are just sort of playing at it.''
 Some see the foliage as New England's single most defining element.
 ''Egypt has the Pyramids,'' Ms. Serra said. ''Paris has the Eiffel Tower. Every place in the world has something special. In New England, foliage and brilliant colors are very special.''
 Where would Connecticut be without its foliage? According to some historians, the state would be right back where it was 200 years ago.
 Brilliant fall foliage, it seems, was not always a given in this part of the country. Early colonists took intricate notes on the natural beauty they saw when they came to New England, but they made few mentions of the fall foliage, said Walter Woodward, an assistant professor in the history department at the University of Connecticut, and the official state historian. ''With all of the accounts of early settlers in New England, there's rarely any mention of the color of leaves in the fall,'' Dr. Woodward said. ''They describe nature in incredible detail, but we often ask 'Where's the fall?'''
 In ''Autumnal Tints,'' Thoreau himself lamented the lack of appreciation for the leaves, and the strange absence of essays and poems about them. ''The autumnal change of our woods has not made a deep impression on our own literature yet,'' he wrote. ''October has hardly tinged our poetry.''
 Kent C. Ryden, an associate professor of American and New England studies at the University of Southern Maine, tried to understand why that was in his book ''Landscape with Figures: Nature and Culture in New England'' (University of Iowa Press, 2001). Dr. Ryden argued that the foliage New Englanders see today was not always part of the collective consciousness of the Europeans who settled here. For many years, he said, it was not even part of the landscape.
 When colonists first arrived in New England, they clear-cut forests to make room for farming and grazing. While about 75 percent of New England is now covered with trees, only about 25 percent of the area was forested in the middle of the 19th century, Dr. Ryden said.
 ''Up until the mid- to late-19th century, there wasn't really a whole lot of foliage to see, let alone to value as a tourist resource,'' he said.
 In the mid-19th century, agriculture began to decline in New England, and hardwood forests slowly grew back, Dr. Ryden said. Still, foliage did not become integral to the region's identity until the 1920's and 1930's, when automobiles made it easier to reach New England. Color photography further enhanced the region's reputation, he said. 
 But to treat fall foliage like a birthright or a constant cultural marker is not historically accurate, he said. The colorful autumns are as much a product of mythmaking as they are of chlorophyll, he said. 
 If projections for global warming are accurate, the region could begin to look as it did 200 years ago. The irony is not lost on Dr. Ryden.
 ''It could become another part of the romanticized New England past,'' he said. ''The good strong Yankee farmers and the foliage, the classic village green and the white church, that whole combination of landscape elements that people get on the bus to see every fall.''

HEADLINE: Delphi Inc., Meet Germany Inc.

BYLINE: By DANIEL GROSS

 BODY:
THE United States and Germany are often depicted as being at opposite poles of global capitalism. 
 The American economy is supposed to sacrifice workers' security for dynamic growth, embracing globalization with comparatively little concern for the loss of jobs at home.
The German nanny state, by comparison, fiercely holds on to its generous cradle-to-grave benefits and job projections at the expense of job creation and vigorous growth.
 Like all stereotypes, these are riddled with holes: the German economy is plenty impressive, with export juggernauts like the industrial conglomerate Siemens, while the typical United States workplace is hardly a Dickensian mill. 
 But two seemingly unrelated changes last week demonstrated how the world's largest economy, the United States', and the third-largest one, Germany's, are dealing with, or failing to deal with, a fundamental challenge: how to outsmart globalization. 
 On Oct. 8, Delphi Inc., the largest auto parts company in the United States, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing, in part, the high cost of its American workers, who earn as much as $65 per hour. 
 And on Oct. 10, Germany threw in the towel on its election -- the one that was supposed to push Germans into confronting their stagnant economy. Instead, Germany's two largest parties, with differing goals, agreed to form a coalition government under the leadership of Angela Merkel. Any true reckoning has been put on hold.
 What happened? In the week before the election, I toured Germany with other journalists and met with politicians, government officials, bankers and corporate executives. At every stop, we heard a similar message. 
 The current regime of slow economic growth and high labor costs, combined with generous social welfare benefits, is unsustainable. And yet we were left with an overriding sense that the country lacked the appetite for change.
 The same held true for Delphi, which was spun off from General Motors in 1999. The structural flaws that caused its collapse -- high-paying jobs and pensions -- have been evident from the 1970's. Yet the unions and Delphi management also couldn't take corrective action rapidly enough to avert disaster.
 It's not that Delphi Inc. and Germany Inc. have stuck their heads in the sand. Far from it. Delphi is a multinational company, with operations in 40 countries. And Germany's blue chips have likewise aggressively sought growth overseas. 
 But many chief executives find it difficult to justify further investment in Germany. It has rigid labor markets, extensive government and union involvement in corporate governance and high regulation (virtually all retailers are shut on Sundays in Germany, which can be hard to support in a country with 11.2 percent unemployment). And the labor reforms enacted by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder were just enough to alienate core voters without actually changing economic conditions much.
 The elevation of Ms. Merkel is revolutionary. She's the first female chancellor, and the first from East Germany. But her party, the Christian Democrats, and its allies did not win enough parliamentary seats to form a government on their own. So after a few weeks of haggling, Ms. Merkel agreed to create a grand coalition with Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats. 
 It's as if George W. Bush and Al Gore formed a joint government in 2000, and split up cabinet agencies -- Democrats in charge of labor and commerce, a Republican at treasury.
 The stakeholders of Germany Inc. -- the voters -- were unwilling to vote for significant change. And they are now guaranteed not to get it.
 Despite the obvious differences in the German and American styles of capitalism, certain similarities are apparent. There's a trans-Atlantic tendency for stakeholders in both countries to see themselves largely as powerless victims of a global economy. 
 In both countries, chief executives in several crucial industries believe they simply can't continue to operate in their home countries if they have to support the pensions, wages and benefits to which their workers have become accustomed. 
 On Monday, Steve Miller, the chief executive of Delphi, said that Delphi's former parent company, General Motors, could be ''headed down the same Chapter 11 path as Delphi, unless there is a dramatic change in the staggering legacy labor burden.''
 And yet wounded, once-proud giants like Delphi and Germany Inc. may find some common cause in their misery. Of the large American automakers, Chrysler was the most at risk in the 1980's. It averted a near-death experience because labor and management struck cost-cutting deals, and because the federal government backed loans to the company. 
 Paradoxically, Chrysler ultimately found salvation by merging with a Germany company. Today, DaimlerChrysler is in far better financial health than either General Motors or Ford.

HEADLINE: A Quake Jolts Armies, Too 

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE and SOMINI SENGUPTA; David Rohde reported from Rawalpindi for this article, and Somini Sengupta from Srinagar.

DATELINE: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan 

 BODY:
MOHAMMED NASIR, a taxi driver from the Pakistani side of Kashmir, soothed his wounded little girl and cursed the soldiers who brought her to a modern, humming military hospital in this Pakistani garrison city. What did the Pakistani Army do for his village in Kashmir, crushed and crippled by last Saturday's earthquake? ''Almost nothing,'' he spat. 
 Yes, they airdropped packets of milk and a few packets of rice, but those disintegrated during the descent, he recalled. Yes, they airlifted his daughter, 6 years old and with a broken leg, but they abandoned the vast majority of the wounded to curse their fate at home. ''We were brought in a small helicopter that carried four,'' Mr. Nasir said bitterly. ''The rest were left.'' 
Mr. Nasir's indictment, born of both rage and reason, did not necessarily reflect all that was being done in the vastness of this calamity by the two armies that have faced each other in the disputed region of Kashmir for 55 years. But in it lay a window into the huge challenge that his government, and that of India, face in the aftermath of an earthquake that struck on Oct. 8.
 Like few things before it, this calamity has tested the mettle of the state in both countries, and no institution more than their armies. 
 The circumstances present slightly different challenges for India and Pakistan. 
 The Pakistani military controls every important institution in its country, starting with the presidency, on a claim that only it can deliver order and honest government now. Will its performance in the earthquake zone prove it to be a bulwark of order and incorruptibility? India, by contrast, has long been seen as an occupying power by many of Kashmir's citizens. Will its efforts endear it to civilians, or alienate them even more?
 Having fought three wars, both countries devote large shares of their budgets to their militaries -- roughly 2.7 percent of gross domestic product in India and about 5 percent of a much smaller gross domestic product in Pakistan. One obvious challenge in Kashmir will be to show that these resources can be used at least as effectively as aid from Islamic charities now raising funds from Saudi Arabia to the United States. 
 That the quake rumbled under the disputed frontier in Kashmir is perhaps the most tragic paradox. It has wrought new ruin on a region already eviscerated by war. 
 Pakistan has long portrayed itself as the true defender of Kashmiris and their call for independence. But featured in an English-language Pakistani newspaper last week was a photograph of Kashmiri men, their fists in the air, in angry protest -- not against the Indian government, but against their own. It was taken in Muzaffarabad, the capital of Pakistani-controlled Kashmir. 
 In Srinagar, the capital of Indian-controlled Kashmir, frustrations with the pace of government relief also ran high. Six days after the quake, there were no tents or blankets for the homeless, bracing against the onset of winter in the hills. They used wood from the rubble as fuel to prepare whatever food they could retrieve. The Indian Army, posted everywhere in these hills, had brought relief rations consisting of about four pounds each of rice and lentils. But the first glimpse of the civilian administration was a medical team that arrived on day six after the quake. 
 ''We feel that we just do not exist,'' said Mohammed Latif Shah, whose mother died in the earthquake in a village near the disputed frontier. ''It is really painful.''
 ''At this moment we feel that we are not part of India,'' said an indignant Syed Akbar Ali Shah, 65, a former porter for the Indian Army. 
 It is in times of catastrophe, as opposed to war, that relations between a nation's soldiers and its citizens can matter most. And in this part of the world, which is among the most militarized anywhere, how the Pakistani and Indian governments respond will certainly be seen as a test of their commitment to the people of Kashmir. 
 ''We thought this would have been an opportunity, would have given a boost to the peace process, would have narrowed the gulf,'' said Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, a Muslim religious leader who leads a coalition of Kashmiri separatist groups called the Hurriyet Conference. ''It hasn't happened. That's unfortunate.'' 
 As the despair over relief supplies shows, there is not much love lost for the Indian Army in Indian-held Kashmir. Still, it has been widely credited there for its initial rescue efforts, including the loss of a half-dozen of its men in one operation on Wednesday. Even Mr. Farooq acknowledged their sacrifice. ''The army especially did help our people in far-flung areas,'' he said. But he was quick to add: ''The presence of the Army itself is not acceptable to Kashmiris.'' 
 That earthquake operations could buy good will among the populace was not lost on Indian troops. The spokesman for the Indian Army, Col. Hemant Juneja, said his soldiers began rescue operations within hours of the quake. More than 40 soldiers lost their lives, he said, and he offered an inventory of all that the military had delivered to survivors, including 18,000 food ration packs, 20,000 pairs of warm pants, 10,000 pairs of winter socks, 51,100 coats, 15,400 waterproof windbreakers, 5,400 mattresses, 3,200 blankets, 3,000 tents. 
 ''It should show the Indian Army's humane face to the civil population, that despite our casualties, despite our damage, the love and affection for the local population is there,'' the colonel said. Indeed, the potential payoff could be large. Good will among civilians could be a key to gathering intelligence, which in turn could be a key to the Indian Army's counterinsurgency drive. 
 On the Pakistani side of the line, the harshest criticism of the government has centered on its initial response. After the quake struck, military officials and the military-dominated government played down its size. Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz said in an interview later that the earthquake had severed communication, cut the main road to Muzaffarabad and made it impossible to assess the impact swiftly. Four hundred casualties among the army slowed the response, he said.
 Where an army dominates a country, it is also easy to blame. It breeds both expectations and suspicion. Today in Pakistan, generals wield enormous power, military intelligence dominates all corners of government, and private companies attached to army welfare funds own everything from housing tracts to bottled water companies.
 But in the days after the quake, Mr. Nasir and others asked where the army was. It was villagers living less than a two-hour drive from an army base who were digging out the dead with their bare hands. A few days later, relief was flowing but there were no soldiers to regulate traffic leading up to the hardest-hit areas in the north. The road was choked with trucks and vans carrying bananas, blankets and anxious relatives. 
 As relief trickled in, the people shivered another night in the hills.

LENGTH: 1277 words

HEADLINE: A Season A Tad Off Color, And Here's Why

BYLINE: By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
FALL arrives in New York state like a prom queen, draped in boastful reds, yellows and rusty browns, perfumed with wood smoke. It saunters through the Appalachians and down the Catskills before taking its final bow in Westchester and New York City.
 The season is important here not only for the spectacle it creates, but also for the tourist economy it supports and the cultural symbol it represents; no season is more strongly identified with the Northeast than fall. Even 150 years ago, Henry David Thoreau realized how special it was.
''October is the month of painted leaves,'' Thoreau wrote in his 1862 essay ''Autumnal Tints.'' ''Their rich glow now flashes round the world.'' 
 But what if the glow wasn't so rich? 
 That is a question some scientists have already begun to ask, and they don't think it is hypothetical. Already this year, throughout the Northeast, the foliage has been late, and, some say, unspectacular. Scientists at the University of New Hampshire project that shifts in the climate caused by global warming will progressively dull the leaves throughout southern New England and New York over the next century. Maples will move north and the remaining oaks and hickories will change colors later and with less verve, they say. If the projections are correct, leaf-peepers may be forced as far north as Canada to for their fix of foliage. 
 Indeed, one scientist says autumn in the region has already lost its brilliance. 
 ''We haven't had a really great display in the last 10 years,'' said Barrett Rock, a professor in natural resources and a researcher at the Complex Systems Research Center at the University of New Hampshire who has studied the effects of global warming on the autumn landscape from New York to Maine. Dr. Rock was the lead author on a federally financed 2001 report, the New England Regional Assessment, that assessed the effects of climate change on the Northeast. 
 This year, the problem has been intense heat in late summer and early fall, which delayed the changing of the leaves and, Dr. Rock said, dulls the foliage. The average temperature in New York in August was 70.6 degrees, nearly 4 degrees higher than the average since 1895, and the fifth highest August average in that period, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The heat did not let up in September, when it was again 4 degrees warmer than average.
 But global warming is a gradual phenomenon, and one warm year does not mean that fall will be this warm every year.
 Nonetheless, scientists like Dr. Rock say there is ample reason to worry. 
 In the 2001 report, Dr. Rock and fellow researchers at the University of New Hampshire and other universities in the region found that New York's average temperature had increased by 1 degree over the last century. The scientists used two different models to project what the Northeast would look like over the next 100 years. 
 Both models, Dr. Rock noted in a telephone interview, are considered ''middle of the road,'' predicting gradual but not extreme warming trends. But both project that global warming will accelerate dramatically in the region. One forecasts an overall temperature increase of 6 degrees by 2090. That would leave Boston looking and feeling like Richmond, Va. The other model projected a climate like Atlanta's, a full 10 degrees warmer than Boston's, according to the report. 
 This year another University of New Hampshire environmental scientist, Cameron P. Wake, issued a report in conjunction with Clean Air Cool Planet, a nonprofit organization that studies climate change in the Northeast. Using different methods from the earlier study, the new report confirmed the warming trend in the Northeast throughout the 20th century, and showed it increasing over the last 30 years. That report did not focus on foliage but found other significant effects to plants and trees, including progressively later bloom dates for lilac trees. 
 The warming trends affect foliage in various ways, Dr. Rock said. As greenhouse gases accumulate and the earth warms, summer weather will linger into fall. That will delay the frosts that degrade chlorophyll and trigger leaves to change. It takes at least one frost in which temperatures fall to 30 degrees Fahrenheit or below to start the changes in the leaves. If those fall frosts are delayed, or the chlorophyll breaks down more gradually, leaf-peepers won't see the vibrant reds they have come to expect, Dr. Rock said. 
 Last week, Marian Travis was decorating a lamp post near her house in Ossining, N.Y., with colorful fake leaves when she realized that something felt wrong though she was getting her neighborhood ready for fall, it felt more like summer.
 ''It didn't even fell like fall,'' she said. ''It is fall by the calendar, so you have to put the decorations up.''
 Ms. Travis said she thinks fall has changed since she was a girl. ''I remember in the fall, I'd walk home from school and there were so many leaves in the street and the gutter,'' she said. ''They don't have them anymore. I don't think the fall is like what we used to have way back.''
 Global warming will affect which tree species can survive in the state and which will move north to cooler climates, scientists say. 
 Maples, with their stunning red, yellow and orange leaves, are beauties in the fall. Thoreau positively gushed over them, writing that they seem to absorb ''all the sunny warmth of the season.'' 
 New York is full of maples, too, but changes in temperature, air quality and rainfall, the 2001 report said, will change the mix of trees in the state's forests.
 Birches and beeches, two other species known for their foliage, can also be expected to migrate north, the report noted. 
 It details other possible effects of global warming on foliage, including increases in plant diseases and insect outbreaks. Warming also increases ground-level ozone, which can damage leaves. 
 But it is not just scientists who have a stake in the changing autumn landscape. The colors of fall are big business for New York's tourism industry. The state maintains a Web site (www.iloveny.com/fall/pages/foliagereport.html) that specifically tracks the progression of the foliage, enlisting about 55 volunteers from all over the state who call and write in to report the quality of the leaves in their areas. A map highlights the regions of the state where the foliage is brightest. 
 Leaf-peepers make up an important portion of New York's tourist population, said Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which runs the state's I Love New York tourism Web site (www.iloveny.state.ny.us/). Summer is the king of tourist seasons in the state, but fall still attracts 21 percent of the yearly visitors, he said. 
 ''Certainly, we depend on beautiful foliage,'' he said. ''A lot of people travel around the state to see the foliage.''
 Peter Barton, a member of the family that owns Barton Orchard, a ''pick-your-own'' farm in Poughquag that attracts more than 100,000 people in the fall, said the last decade has been marked by more extreme weather, another expected effect of global warming.
 ''From my point of view as a grower, the last decade we've seen much more volatility,'' he said. ''The storms have been more volatile.''
 He said he was concerned about the effect of global warming on plants, even if the increase in temperature isn't as much as 6 or 10 degrees.
 ''A simple 1 or 2 degree change can change the organisms that can exist here,'' he said.
 If that happens, and the autumn prom queen starts dressing in brown or dull green, autumn in New York could look a lot different.

HEADLINE: Attack of the Aliens

BYLINE: By Henry Tepper. 
Henry Tepper is director of the Nature Conservancy's New York State program.

 BODY:
NEWS that dreaded snakehead fish were found this summer living in a pond in Queens is worrisome but not that surprising. After all, the New York Police Department and the city's park rangers have been called on to deal with a fully grown Bengal tiger living in a Harlem apartment and a disoriented Burmese python out for a walk with its owner in Central Park. 
 Our Pleistocene mind is still wired to recoil at the thought of snakes, tigers and other major carnivores. But our brains have yet to catch up with the modern threats posed by the introduction of invasive species like the snakehead fish, the Asian long-horned beetle, the mile-a-minute weed and purple loosestrife. 
On their home turf, these plants and animals are kept in check by natural controls, like predators and limited food supplies. But when one of these species is introduced, accidentally or intentionally, into a new landscape -- one not adapted to its presence -- the consequences can be devastating. Unchecked, some invasive species can quickly spread, crowding out native species and costing billions in property damage and lost economic productivity. 
 Scientists estimate that thousands of new species are introduced each year around the world, and as many as 15 percent will become invasive species. While the percentage may seem small, it is one reason we now face the greatest extinction of native species since the death of dinosaurs. 
 The potential for catastrophic impact to New York State's society, economy and environment is very real because each time an invasive species takes hold, it rearranges the natural balance of life. As in a game of Russian roulette, the trigger is pulled with each new arrival. 
 New Yorkers now have the opportunity to do something. In response to this threat, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature created a task force to explore the invasive species issue and give recommendations by next month. After working for more than a year, the task force (of which my organization is a part) issued a draft report in August. 
 The report tells us there is precious little time to waste as a number of species are poised to invade New York. The threats we face are chilling. Swede midge, which arrived from Canada last year, can destroy our broccoli, cauliflower and cabbage crops if it becomes established. Southern bacterial wilt, from Africa and South America, could contaminate our soils and drastically reduce the yields of potatoes, tomatoes, eggplant and peppers. Escaped bighead and silver carp from the Chicago River could seriously disrupt the ecology of New York waterways if they manage to crash through the electrical barrier that keeps them from entering the Great Lakes. The emerald ash borer has wreaked havoc in Michigan and is thought to be as close as London, Ontario. Chinese mitten crabs are for sale in live food markets in Manhattan and their release into the Hudson River could change the ecology of the estuary. 
 No silver bullet exists to stop the spread of invasive plants and creatures but there are things we can do. As recommended in the report, prevention, early detection, rapid response, control and management and education are still some of the best tools we have to protect our environment. 
 Invasive species cost the United States an estimated $120 billion a year, according to Cornell University. No figures are available for New York State, but we know the annual bill thus far for the eradication of the Asian long-horned beetle in New York City and on Long Island ranges from $13 million to $40 million per year. Tens of thousands of shade trees have been sacrificed to keep the pest from spreading and infecting hardwoods, sugar maples and the rest of our forestry stock. 
 West Nile virus, zebra mussels, chronic wasting disease, water chestnut, sea lamprey, swallowwort and watermilfoil are just a few examples of invasive species that have already cost tens of millions of dollars to control in New York.
 We can stack the odds in our favor if we take action now. The task force report is the first step toward a strong plan of action, but stronger statewide coordination and a $10 million dedicated annual budget by the Pataki administration and its successor are necessary for the near future. For the long term, however, the state needs a master plan to deal with snakeheads and all invasive species waiting at New York's gates.

HEADLINE: Catskills Casino? We Need the Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 ''Bad Bets in the Catskills'' (editorial, Sept. 25) doesn't discuss what is really needed in Sullivan County. I'm talking about jobs.
Visitors who once vacationed in our area can recall the busy Broadway in Monticello and Main Street in South Fallsburg and remember the family businesses that thrived for generations. They've now closed, leaving boarded-up stores, no pedestrian traffic and few jobs. 
 The per capita incomes in Sullivan County are below $19,000, with 16.3 percent of the population and 11.6 percent of families living below the poverty line.
 Why would anyone suggest that gamblers from New York State continue to take their money and business to New Jersey and Connecticut without pursuing ways to keep those dollars and jobs in our state? 
 Your contention that casinos in Sullivan County would hurt the environment is absurd. The proposed Monticello Raceway site is not even near the Neversink River nor the Shawangunk Ridge. Monticello Raceway is an established gaming location. No fishing streams nor pristine forests would be ''sliced and diced by roads and traffic'' should a casino be built at the raceway. 
 The only thing that is getting sliced and diced is our many union men and women who live in Sullivan County who can't find work.
 The vast majority of the land-use experts, constituents and other Sullivan County residents I have spoken with have said that Monticello Raceway would be a natural location for a casino that would not disturb our environment. This is an opportunity for Sullivan County to establish higher-paying jobs, which in turn would increase our per capita wages, providing a stronger tax base.
 Our economy is seasonal. We need year-round jobs desperately, jobs that support the merchants who live and work in Sullivan County. Unlike neighboring Orange County, with its cities and suburban malls, Sullivan County has only two major grocery stores and a few small malls. We also have more tax-exempt property than most other counties in the state, meaning that we need to find ways of building our tax base.

Anthony P. Cellini
Supervisor, Town of Thompson
Monticello, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Trying to Limit Gas-Price Shock to Just Once a Day

BYLINE: By STACY ALBIN

 BODY:
IN the wake of Hurricane Katrina, gasoline stations sometimes changed their prices two or three times a day. The rapid changes left many Long Islanders scratching their heads over how gas prices are set. And it led to the introduction of a bill in the State Senate that would restrict service station owners to just one price increase every 24 hours. 
 Gas prices are set in two ways, according to Eric DeGesero, executive vice president of the Fuel Merchants Association of New Jersey. One method, he said, is based on New York Mercantile Exchange prices for gasoline futures -- bulk contracts to deliver fuel on a set date in the future. 
The second method is used by major oil companies like ExxonMobil, which refine their own fuel and generally do not buy much gasoline on the commodities markets, Mr. DeGesero said. 
 Kathryn Odessa, the executive director of the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association, said that service stations usually raise their prices in response to actions by wholesalers. Most dealers lease their stations from a major oil company, she said, and are required to buy their gas only from that company. Any time the price of oil increases, the oil companies quickly pass the cost along to the dealers, Ms. Odessa said.
 And after Katrina, prices shot up. A gallon of regular unleaded cost as much as $3.79 at a station in Cedarhurst on Sept. 8, according to NewYorkGasPrices.com, a Web site where drivers report the prices they see posted.
 By last Tuesday, the Web site showed prices on Long Island ranging from $2.69 to $3.05 for a gallon of regular unleaded.
 Passing on wholesale price increases quickly to consumers is a nationwide practice for dealers, said Mr. DeGesero. Any increase in futures contracts for unleaded gasoline has an immediate effect at the pumps, because representatives from major oil companies phone or e-mail dealers to inform them of a wholesale price change for the next day, said Mr. DeGesero and Omar Koseoglu, who owns a Citgo station in Point Lookout. In especially tumultuous situations, like the weeks following Katrina, some wholesalers changed their prices two or three times a day.
 Irwin Kellner, a professor of economics at Hofstra University and the chief economist for North Fork Bank, said that gas stations typically base their prices on what it will cost to refill their tanks, a principle called replacement-cost theory, which he said is used by many businesses that constantly replenish inventories. Stations typically have one to three days' supply in their tanks.
 Oil companies do not require service stations to peg their cost of gas directly to replacement cost, said Mr. Koseoglu, who has 25 years' experience in the gasoline business, including ownership of a station in Point Lookout. He said that a station's cost of labor, rent and utilities all go into setting the final gas price at the station, and that a dealer's profit on gasoline is usually 5 to 10 per cent. When prices are very high, ''you make less than 5 percent,'' he said. ''You can't make too much, because the gas prices are too high.''
 Competitors' prices are also a factor. Mr. Koseoglu said he tried to keep his prices as low as possible, in order to compete with the Mobil and Hess stations three miles away in Long Beach. 
 The pending legislation would limit replacement-cost increases when prices fluctuate rapidly. 
 ''Consumers must be protected from unscrupulous retailers looking to capitalize on the current situation,'' the bill, sponsored by Senator Carl L. Marcellino of Syosset, proclaims. ''Price gouging at the pump is a potentially serious epidemic in this climate.'' The bill, which would impose a $1,000 fine for each violation, passed the Senate by 56 votes to 3 on Sept. 20. The Assembly has not yet considered such a bill.
 The Senate measure would not affect wholesalers. But Ms. Odessa said that the proposed legislation would be unfair and ineffective, because gasoline pricing is a complicated matter that is for the most part beyond the control of service station owners. 
 For example, she said, state law prohibits stations from selling gas at less than 95 percent of its cost. That law, which was enacted in 2003 and expires in April 2007, was meant to keep dealers from using predatory pricing to gain market share, according to the Empire State Petroleum Association, in Albany. 
 Legislating the price at the pump is not the answer, Mr. DeGesero said, adding that a New Jersey law similar to the proposed New York legislation, on the books since 1938, had not restrained prices.
 ''Oil companies make their money on the exploration and refining end of the business,'' Mr. DeGesero said. ''One common benchmark for the financial health of the major oil companies is the difference between what they pay for a barrel of crude and what they get for the refined products that come from a barrel of crude.'' 
 The difference, known as crack spread, was $4 to $10 a barrel in the 1990's, Mr. DeGesero said. Since early 2000, the crack spread has risen to $20 a barrel and then $30 a barrel immediately after Katrina, he said.
 Citing statistics from the Energy Information Administration, which is part of the United States Department of Energy, Mr. DeGesero said that average crude oil prices had increased from $24.10 a barrel in 2002 to $28.53 in 2003 and $36.97 in 2004. This year, the price was more than $40 a barrel until early spring, when it jumped to more than $60.
 Retail prices have followed crude prices, rising to an average of $2.90 a gallon for unleaded regular in New York last Monday, from $2.09 a year ago, NewYorkGasPrices.com reported. 
 Mr. DeGesero said it was hard to tell how much of the increase in crude oil prices was driven only by supply and demand. The International Energy Agency in Paris says worldwide demand for crude oil has increased to about 84 million barrels a day, of which the United States consumes about 22 million.
 ''I'd be angry if I were a consumer,'' Mr. DeGesero said. ''I don't like paying more for the gas I put in my car. But I wouldn't like it even more if I couldn't get any.''
