LENGTH: 2165 words

HEADLINE: Reaching Out For All the Help They Can Get

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: SCOTCH PLAINS 

 BODY:
WITH Rudolph W. Giuliani at his side, Douglas R. Forrester seemed like a different man. ''We love you Doug,'' one man shouted as Mr. Forrester beamed.
 Clearly buoyed by his companion as well as a surge in recent opinion polls, Mr. Forrester said: ''Oh, wait until that hits politicsnj,'' referring to a popular political Web site. ''We're not going to go down that path again.''
Not one usually known for his light touch or his embrace of the risque remark, Mr. Forrester may have felt emboldened on Wednesday afternoon by the presence of the talismanic former mayor of New York City, who had come to campaign for him at a modest Knights of Columbus hall here. 
 ''Another reason we're going to win this thing,'' Mr. Forrester said at one point as Mr. Giuliani smiled approvingly, ''is that we are getting help from some of our friends who are national figures, and we've got one of the best here with us.''
 With that, the crowd of about 150 party stalwarts, studded with local officials, launched into a chant of ''Rudy! Rudy!''
 It was just the sort of lift that Mr. Forrester and his Democratic opponent, Senator Jon S. Corzine, are desperate for these days as they look longingly to the brightest lights in their respective parties to define their opponents and themselves to a crucial clutch of undecided voters. 
 ''Neither candidate has found a compelling argument that knocks out the other or is decisive for their candidacy,'' said Kathleen Hall Jamieson, director of the Annenberg Public Policy Center of the University of Pennsylvania. ''It's like when there's parity in commercial products. After you've thrown everything at the other side, you bring in everything else you can and try to give this the standing of a national contest.''
 So it was hardly a coincidence that while Mr. Giuliani was venturing to Scotch Plains on a rain-soaked Wednesday afternoon, John Edwards, the former North Carolina senator and vice presidential nominee, was attending a luncheon at the New Jersey Center for the Performing Arts.
 And although the $1,500-a-plate gathering was organized by the state's Democratic Assembly Campaign Committee and Mr. Corzine was off stumping in another part of the state, Mr. Edwards took the opportunity to praise the gubernatorial candidate's ''strength, character and leadership.''

Embracing the Moment
 The added jolt provided by national politicians with marquee names is sure to be embraced by candidates and crowds alike. After all, the electorate has hardly been transfixed by the race, which has seemed to many potential voters to be an exchange of indistinguishable and nasty charges between two candidates making the same grand promises about lowering property taxes and raising the ethical bar.
 So what if some of those voters are too unfamiliar with Mr. Forrester to take his word that he is not -- as the Corzine campaign has repeatedly implied -- a right-wing Trojan horse who would be a captive of the Bush administration?
 Let them ask Mr. Giuliani or Senator Mel Martinez of Florida, who visited the state last weekend, or John McCain, the iconic senator from Arizona who is coming to New Jersey next week, or even the likeable first lady, Laura Bush.
 And for those who are starting to believe, as Forrester supporters insist, that Mr. Corzine is little more than an ethically conflicted multimillionaire trying to buy his way to the state's most powerful office? 
 Well, they only have to listen to the most magnetic Democrat of all these days, former President Bill Clinton, who said at a recent rally at Kean University that Mr. Corzine, a former chairman of Goldman Sachs, was the most qualified candidate for governor he had ever seen. Or to John Kerry, last year's Democratic presidential candidate, who also campaigned for Mr. Corzine. Or to the former Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, who appeared with Mr. Corzine in Belmar last week. 
 In the days ahead, New Jerseyans will also be treated to the sight of two of Mr. Corzine's more celebrated colleagues: Senator Hillary Clinton of New York, who will no doubt attest to Mr. Corzine's virtues at a pair of fund-raising events this week, and Senator Barack Obama of Illinois -- the most electrifying speaker at the Democratic National Convention in 2004 -- who has also agreed to campaign.
 While these high-profile surrogates will not fundamentally alter the dynamic of the race -- people vote for the candidates, or so the political axiom goes, and not for those who endorse them -- they can serve an important motivational function in a race like the one under way in New Jersey, which the latest polls show to have closed to a single-digit lead for Mr. Corzine. 
 ''They shore up the party base, making sure that the faithful turn out, and they show that they think the races are important, which sometimes they aren't,'' said Larry Sabato, a political science professor at the University of Virginia.
 In the case of the current campaign, voters have only just begun to tune into a race that had been considered uninteresting with a result that is a foregone conclusion. ''New Jersey is a heavily Democratic state and Corzine has been expected to win by just about everybody,'' Mr. Sabato said. 
 But with the latest poll numbers -- a WNBC/Marist survey made public on Tuesday showed Mr. Corzine's lead at a single percentage point, a virtual dead heat -- and a greater focus on the opponents, their nationally prominent advocates serve the increasingly important function of at once grabbing the headlines and deflecting potentially damaging attacks. 
 For Mr. Forrester, the challenge is to show that he is a different sort of Republican than President George W. Bush, whose approval rating in New Jersey has slipped to a dismal 34 percent, according to a recent Star-Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers poll. 
 And for its part, the Corzine campaign is running commercials calling him ''George Bush's choice'' for governor, and has taken up where Frank Lautenberg left off in his successful Senate campaign in 2002 by calling attention to what they say are Mr. Forrester's common positions with the Bush administration on visceral issues like new laws banning assault weapons and government financing for some types of embryonic stem cell research.
 Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, arguably the most popular Democrat in the state these days, went so far last week as to dare the Forrester campaign to invite President Bush to the state to campaign.
 For now, Mr. Forrester says ''there are no plans to do so.''
 Instead, Mr. Forrester has responded by tying himself to Republicans from the moderate wing of the party, including former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who is currently appearing in a Forrester campaign ad in which he explicitly vouches for the candidate's credentials on abortion rights. 
 ''He's a moderate,'' Mr. Kean says of Mr. Forrester, who was pension director in his administration. ''He supports a woman's right to choose.''
 As David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University, said: ''The Tom Kean ad was one of the most memorable of the campaign so far. It's been absolutely essential for Forrester to establish his moderate credentials, and it seems like it's more effective when it's not coming from him.''
 In much the same way, visits from such luminaries as Mr. Giuliani and Mr. McCain as well as Mr. Martinez, a prominent Hispanic member of the Republican firmament, are designed to frame Mr. Forrester as an independent-thinking and moderately disposed member of a party whose center of gravity is in the culturally conservative regions of the South and West.
 By contrast, it is Democrats and not Mr. Forrester who are going out of their way to talk about visits to the state by Vice President Dick Cheney and Mr. Bush's chief political adviser, Karl Rove -- two distinctly conservative and polarizing figures who attended low-key yet highly profitable fund-raising events here for the Republican candidate earlier this year.
 The dilemma for Mr. Forrester, and one that Corzine aides delight in pointing out, is that there are many Republicans in New Jersey who are opposed to abortion rights and gun control, and who vote in large part on those issues. 
 As the final weeks of the campaign unfold, the challenge for Mr. Forrester will be to appeal to middle-of-the-road independent voters without alienating the core conservatives whose support will be crucial for him to become the 52nd elected governor of New Jersey.
 ''If you're Doug Forrester you do want to have the best of both worlds,'' Mr. Rebovich said. ''You don't want to be associated with the administration but you have to find a way to satisfy your base and give public the impression that you are respected in national circles.''
 The calculations for Mr. Corzine are quite different. For more than a decade, the state's electorate has been leaning Democratic in national elections, meaning that unlike Mr. Forrester, he can benefit from his perceived links to the national party. 
 Rather, Mr. Corzine's problem stems from his relationships with such Democrats as former Gov. James E. McGreevey and former Senator Robert Torricelli, both of whom removed themselves from public office under ethical clouds, as well as Charles Kushner, a developer and major Democratic fund-raiser with whom he tried to purchase the New Jersey Nets. 
 Mr. Kushner later pleaded guilty to federal charges of tax evasion, making illegal campaign contributions and witness intimidation. 
 As infrequently as he likes to talk about it, Mr. Corzine first came to prominence in the state party during his Senate campaign in 2000, largely on the strength of his generous contributions to powerful local Democratic leaders and organizations. Similarly, his millions of dollars in contributions helped him line up the support from county bosses earlier this year to force Mr. Codey out of a possible run for governor.
 Mr. Corzine, for his part, has been somewhat erratic in his efforts to put some distance between those party figures and himself.
 Despite the fact that he talks regularly to Mr. Torricelli, his primary political mentor when he entered politics, Mr. Corzine said in an interview several months ago that their relationship was overblown by the news media and that ''most of the folks on my team are not really thrilled with Bob Torricelli.'' 
 And in response to a question about words of praise he had for Mr. McGreevey this summer, Mr. Corzine said during the last week's debate, broadcast on the radio station known as New Jersey 101.5, that Mr. McGreevey had ''failed as a governor,'' characterizing his previous comments as mere political niceties.

Costly, Yet Uninspiring
 It was hardly inspiring stuff, but that could be said of much of what voters have been hearing from the candidates in the course of watching their combined $30 million worth of advertising. 
 In fact, things have become so blurred that a race that was once billed both as a referendum on the Democrats running New Jersey and on the Republicans running the United States may turn out to be neither.
 For instance, political analysts are looking to the governor's race in Virginia and not New Jersey -- the only two such contests in the country in this off year -- as a sort of measure of Mr. Bush's popularity.
 Indeed, with the president's national approval rating at 39 percent in a recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, it is not unreasonable to expect that the Republican candidate there may pay a political price for the problems swirling around the White House: a sluggish economy, serious concerns about slow progress in Iraq, the administration's perceived mishandling of Hurricane Katrina and the much-maligned nomination of Harriet Miers to the United States Supreme Court.
 New Jersey, on the other hand, is more complicated. For many voters, the financial and ethical problems in Trenton have rivaled anything they have seen from the Republican-controlled White House and Congress. And according to the Star Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers poll, voters are just as likely to associate Mr. Corzine with Mr. McGreevey's problems as they are to link Mr. Forrester with the president's.
 ''Right now, it's feeling kind of random,'' said Jennifer Duffy, a political analyst for The Cook Political Report, a nonpartisan newsletter. ''I think that if Bush is hurting Forrester, McGreevey is hurting Corzine at about the same level.''
 In the closing days and weeks of the campaign, it may well be up to the high-profile surrogates to do what both candidates have not: bring excitement to a somewhat tawdry campaign that has yet to capture New Jersey's attention.
 ''This election will be determined in large measure by the impressions people have that will be gleaned by the information they get over the last week or so,'' said former Gov. Jim Florio. ''There's just so much going on the world that is of concern to people that this has not appeared to be a high value item in terms of their attention.''

HEADLINE: Another Option to Consider for Plum Island 

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
MICHAEL CHERTOFF, the secretary of Homeland Security, has agreed to consider upgrading the Plum Island Animal Disease Center at its current security level instead of replacing it with a new $450 million center on the island or elsewhere for research of biological terrorism.
 Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, and Representative Timothy Bishop, Democrat of Southampton, said they gained the agreement to consider keeping the lab's Biosafety Level 3 status during a meeting with Mr. Chertoff earlier this month. Both are trying to save the lab, its 200 jobs and its current operations, studying foreign animal diseases that are not lethal to humans.
The Department of Homeland Security announced in August that it would study a biological and agriculture defense facility to replace Plum Island, but the department did not specify whether it would be on the island or somewhere else. 
 A new center researching bioterrorism and agroterrorism, the use of biological agents to harm the nation's food supply, would almost certainly have Level 4 status, the highest security designation for labs. 
 Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Bishop said in a telephone conference with reporters after the meeting that they told Mr. Chertoff that they and the vast majority of their constituents opposed a Biosafety Level 4 laboratory on the 840-acre island. Level 4 status would allow research on diseases fatal to humans and animals and with no known cure.
 Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Bishop said Mr. Chertoff had not renewed a pledge by Tom Ridge, the former secretary of Homeland Security, that Plum Island would remain at Level 3. But they said they argued that the work done at Plum Island now was crucial and warranted upgrading the 50-year-old laboratory to continue at Level 3 designation. 
 ''The calculus changes dramatically if you get a Biosafety Level 4 that is looking at human diseases and even looking at how animal viruses and pathogens jump from the animal world to the human world, and it just is very hard to justify putting that kind of facility in the midst of one of the most populated areas where workers would be going back and forth all the time,'' Mrs. Clinton said.
 Mr. Bishop said a Level 4 lab on Plum Island could allow study of diseases like avian flu, which has killed millions of birds in nearly a dozen countries and infected more than 100 people, including 60 who died.
 ''Level 4 laboratories study diseases for which there is no vaccine or therapy and they are highly dangerous, life-threatening diseases that can be transmitted to humans,'' he said. ''Our concern is to introduce that to the North Fork of Long Island is just something that we don't consider to be in the public interest.'' 
 Plum Island is about a mile and a half off the end of the North Fork. Its staff of 100 scientists and 100 support workers commute by ferry from Orient Point and Connecticut.
 Level 4 labs for research on human pathogens are at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and Fort Detrick in Frederick, Md. More than 10 Level 4 labs are operating or planned elsewhere.
 Representative Peter T. King, Republican of Seaford and chairman of the House Committee on Homeland Security, gave qualified support to Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Bishop. In a statement issued on Tuesday, Mr. King said that he would work with them and Mr. Chertoff ''in attempting to find a way to upgrade Plum Island to continue research at a Biosafety Level 3 in a manner consistent with our homeland security needs.''
 But Roger Breeze, the Plum Island laboratory director from 1987 to 1995, said that New York could not compete for the new center, which is scheduled to open in 2011, unless it supported Level 4. ''When the competition is for a combined BSL 3 and BSL 4 facility and you are only proposing a BSL 3, you are not a competitor,'' Dr. Breeze said.
 The Level 3 lab at Plum Island is designed to allow research on diseases, like foot-and-mouth disease, that are highly infectious in animals but far less dangerous to humans. Plum Island employs negative air pressure, sealed laboratories and rigorous shower and cleaning routines to keep biological agents from escaping. All animals used in research are incinerated on the island. 
 In a Level 4 lab, scientists studying deadly human and animal diseases would wear full-body protective suits fitted for piped-in air, and security would be tightened.
 Asked if Mr. Chertoff seemed willing to consider upgrading the island laboratory without adding Level 4, Mrs. Clinton said: ''He was open to that. He said he was going to be guided by the scientists who he has appointed to look into this.'' 
 Valerie Smith, a spokeswoman for the Department of Homeland Security, confirmed Tuesday that Mr. Chertoff had agreed to look at upgrading Plum Island as a Level 3 lab as part of the study. ''All options are on the table,'' she said. ''We are open to proposals from officials and groups across the county.''
 Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Bishop said they requested that the study look not only at keeping the laboratory at Level 3 but also at the cost of closing it and cleaning up the island. ''If these assessments are made objectively and accurately, then Plum Island will get the consideration it deserves,'' Mrs. Clinton said.
 She and Mr. Bishop said they also sought assurances that other types of security-related research would continue on the island if Homeland Security abandoned the lab. They mentioned Stony Brook University, Brookhaven National Laboratory and the Cold Spring Harbor laboratory as possible users. 
 David Kapell, the mayor of Greenport, said that by opposing a Level 4 lab, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Bishop had assured that the lab would close. 
 ''It is a pipe dream to think that the lab will survive on Plum Island if it is not allowed to expand to Biosafety Level 4,'' he said. ''Ruling Level 4 out effectively seals its fate and invites any other community out there to steal our lab from us.''
 Mr. Kapell said his village board recently passed a resolution supporting a Level 4 lab. 
 But Anne Hopkins, the president of the Orient Association, said she and others had misgivings about trying to save the laboratory.
 ''Maybe it has outlived its function,'' she said. ''Suppose the laboratory were given up. Couldn't Plum Island become a fantastic place for another purpose, whether housing or scientific research or some combination that would provide just as many jobs and opportunities? Let's not jump in right away and say it has to be saved as an animal research lab.''
 Joshua Y. Horton, the supervisor for the Town of Southold, said that closing the lab would be a ''staggering blow'' to the North Fork economy and that the possibility compelled consideration of Level 4 status. 
 ''There would be a lot of opposition from the residential community at first because I don't think there is a real understanding of the implications of Level 4,'' he said.
 Gwynn Schroeder, the executive director of the North Fork Environmental Council in Mattituck, said the absence of an evacuation plan made Level 4 too great a risk. She said that if the lab closed, jobs would be created by a remediation project and by new research on the island. 
 Ms. Hopkins said she and people she knew were apprehensive that the laboratory would be upgraded to Level 4. ''We don't want Biosafety Level 4,'' she said. ''That's got us very concerned.''

HEADLINE: Detectives' Union Backs Mayor Despite Pledge by Ferrer

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU and NICHOLAS CONFESSORE

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg received the support of the city's police detectives yesterday despite a campaign promise earlier in the week by his rival, Fernando Ferrer, to spare the police force from budget cuts.
 The Detectives' Endowment Association, the union that represents 15,000 current and retired police detectives, announced the endorsement at a news conference during which its members presented the mayor with a lapel pin of a detective's gold shield set against an American flag.
In the 2001 mayoral election, the union endorsed Mr. Bloomberg's rival, Mark Green. 
 But Michael J. Palladino, the union's president, said yesterday that Mr. Bloomberg had earned its backing with his commitment to public safety and his support for law enforcement activities, ranging from routine patrols to counterterrorism operations. 
 ''Mayor Bloomberg inherited this city in a state of both fiscal and physical disarray following the 9/11 attack,'' Mr. Palladino said. ''He made some difficult and some unpopular decisions to bring back the city to fiscal stability.''
 During a mayoral forum on Friday, Mr. Ferrer said he would not cut funding to the city's police force if elected. 
 Mr. Bloomberg has made no such commitments. His administration cut $412.5 million this year from the Police Department's budget as part of an overall reduction of city expenses. Next year, city officials face a projected budget gap of $4.5 billion.
 Mr. Palladino said that Mr. Ferrer's promise of no cuts to police funding was not enough to sway his group. 
 The union's endorsement comes as its members are negotiating with the city for a new contract; the previous contract expired in February 2004. 
 Mr. Palladino said the two issues were separate, though he acknowledged the endorsement could not hurt. ''How well could I do at the bargaining table if I'm negotiating with Mayor Bloomberg but I'm endorsing somebody else?'' he asked. 
 Mr. Bloomberg campaigned yesterday in Brooklyn before speaking at a memorial service in Staten Island to commemorate the second anniversary of the crash of the ferry Andrew J. Barberi that killed 11 people. 
 Meanwhile, Mr. Ferrer, who is of Puerto Rican descent, traveled to Puerto Rico to meet with its governor, Anibal Acevedo-Vila, and to attend a fund-raiser organized by the Puerto Rico for Ferrer Committee. 
 Mr. Acevedo-Vila told The Associated Press yesterday that Puerto Ricans should urge their family members in New York City to vote for Mr. Ferrer.
 ''Fernando Ferrer represents the best of those Puerto Ricans who for many reasons decided to live in the United States, but who never forgot their roots here in Puerto Rico,'' Mr. Acevedo-Vila said. 
 Mr. Ferrer was to return to New York early today.
 Last week, Mr. Ferrer was endorsed by the Empire State Pride Agenda, a gay rights group. The group's executive director, Alan Van Capelle, cited Mr. Ferrer's support for gay marriages and Mr. Bloomberg's decision to appeal a state court ruling allowing gay couples to marry.
 The mayor, who has said he personally supports gay marriage, has said that it would be illegal for him to authorize it until the courts clarified the law.

HEADLINE: Bush's Ancestors

BYLINE: By Sean Wilentz. 
Sean Wilentz is a professor of American history at Princeton. His new book, ''The Rise of American Democracy,'' is out this month from W.W. Norton.''

 BODY:
Ever since Ronald Reagan's election in 1980, the strength of American conservatism has largely confounded historians and intellectuals. Before then, a generation of influential scholars claimed that liberalism was the core of all American political thinking and suggested that it always would be. Well into the 1970's, many observers wondered whether a Republican Party that allied itself with the conservative movement could long survive. 
History has, to say the least, disproved these judgments. Yet many prominent liberals continue to see contemporary conservatism as a rhetorical smoke screen intended to deceive the masses -- even as conservatives often trace their movement back no farther than William F. Buckley Jr.'s founding of National Review in 1955, fusing religious and pro-business-minded voters. Such thinking, however, slights the coherence and durability of conservative politics in America. The blend of businessmen's aversion to government regulation, down-home cultural populism and Christian moralism that sustains today's Republican Party is a venerable if loosely knit philosophy of government dating back to long before the right-wing upsurge that prepared the way for Reagan's presidency. A few pundits and political insiders have likened the current Republicans to the formidable, corporate-financed political machine behind President William McKinley at the end of the 19th century. The admiration Karl Rove has expressed for the machine strengthens the historical connection. Yet neither conservatives nor liberals have fully recognized that the Bush administration's political and ideological recipe was invented decades before McKinley by a nearly forgotten American institution: the Whig Party of the 1830's and 40's. 
 The Whigs arose in 1834 to oppose Andrew Jackson's anti-elitist Democratic Party. Furious at Jackson's destruction of the privately controlled, all-powerful Second Bank of the United States and his forceful claims for presidential authority, the Whigs built a national following dedicated to protecting business and reducing federal economic regulation. Enriching the rich, they proclaimed, would eventually enrich everyone else. By combining a pro-business conservatism geared to the common man with an evangelical Christian view of social virtues and vices, they won the presidency twice in the 1840's and controlled either the House or the Senate for most of the decade. In the Senate, the legendary Henry Clay of Kentucky and Daniel Webster of Massachusetts magnified the Whig Party's influence far beyond Capitol Hill with the power of their oratory. Insofar as perennial themes shape our politics, it is remarkable how so many of contemporary conservatism's central ideas and slogans renovate old Whig appeals.
 The Opportunity Society and the Attack on Big Government: Modern conservatism rests on the proposition that Democrats and liberals thrive on a huge, wasteful federal bureaucracy that discourages individual initiative and lavishes public money on the liberals' shiftless political base. In his first Inaugural Address, Reagan denounced ''government by an elite group,'' by which he unmistakably meant parasitic liberal Democrats.
 In the 1830's and 40's, Whigs said much the same about the Jacksonians. They charged that President Jackson had established an executive tyranny, while Jackson's followers, as the Whig journalist Horace Greeley wrote, had turned government into ''an agency mainly of corruption, oppression and robbery.'' In defiance of Jacksonian despotism, one North Carolinian declared in an 1835 editorial, the Whigs rallied ''in defense of LIBERTY against POWER.'' The Whigs particularly objected, like Reagan and his successors, to federal regulation of business and financial matters. A typical Whig editorial from 1837 denounced the Democrats for warring on ''the merchants and mercantile interests'' in order to support federal power.
 A century and a half before Reagan's election, the Whigs worked out the basic ideas of supply-side, trickle-down economics. They acclaimed the romance of risk and private investment and a compelling but simplistic view of America as, in one widely used Whig phrase, ''a country of self-made men.'' These views would reappear in Reagan's and Newt Gingrich's celebrations of a coming ''opportunity society,'' later reformulated by George W. Bush as the ''ownership society.'' The Whigs also dismissed the Jacksonians' attacks on the privileged classes as demagogic -- much as Bush, running in 2000 as a unifying ''compassionate conservative,'' labeled his opponent's criticisms of corporate power and tax breaks for the wealthy a mean-spirited effort ''to wage class warfare to get ahead.''
 Of course, there are significant differences between the Whigs and today's conservatives. Governing in an age before giant private corporations, the Whigs saw federal spending on the nation's infrastructure as imperative to economic development. On this point, modern G.O.P. dogma departs from Whig principles -- a difference that has recently caused the Bush administration severe embarrassment.
 Conservative Populism: Modern conservatives present themselves as the party of the oppressed taxpayer and small businessman -- citizens Reagan lionized as ''hard-working Americans.'' Similarly, leading Whig operatives, like the New York wire-puller Thurlow Weed, refined a vocabulary and a public image befitting a party of the toiling American majority pitted against selfish politicians. 
 Whig rhetoric departed fundamentally from the aristocratic hauteur and gloominess that old-line conservatives inherited from the defunct Federalist Party. On the political stump, the example of the buckskinned Whig congressman and Tennessee rifleman Davy Crockett was widely imitated. Even classical-style orators like Webster learned to put aside their Cicero on the campaign trail, declare themselves rip-snorting Democrats -- and threaten to punch out anybody who said otherwise. The Whigs also invented new satirical characters who, in newspapers and onstage, ridiculed politicians who ''manage to git hold of the money of the people and keep turning it to their own account.'' While they cast themselves and their rich supporters as just plain folks, the Whigs portrayed the Democrats as smooth-handed, Champagne-drinking, out-of-touch professional politicians. The appeals helped the Whigs win the presidency in 1840 with their famous ''log cabin and hard cider'' campaign, presenting their well-born presidential candidate, William Henry Harrison, as a plebeian hero who lived in a humble abode and drank the common frontiersman's brew. 
 Today's Republicans have repeated the makeover. In the 1970's, the conservative movement's adoption of the sunny-tempered Hollywood cowboy Reagan as its leader in place of the dour, bespectacled Barry Goldwater was the great breakthrough of modern conservative populism. Thereafter, the transformation of the Massachusetts-born patrician George H.W. Bush into a lover of pork rinds and of his Andover-, Yale- and Harvard-educated son into a rugged Texas pioneer extended the conservative populist theme. The Democrats, meanwhile, remain trapped in the public's image of them as effete ''brie and Chablis'' liberals. 
 Moralism, Self-Reform and the Culture War: Today's Republican Party owes a great deal to its political alliance with resurgent conservative evangelical Christians, part of a wider conservative attack on liberals as the enemies of traditional morality. That attack reinforces the fundamental idea of the ''opportunity society'': personal failure stems not from economic and social inequalities but from the moral failings of thriftless, heedless, lawless, libertine and lazy individuals -- precisely the sorts of people (conservatives charge) liberals want to coddle with needless, destructive social spending. 
 The Whigs portrayed the Jacksonians in very similar terms. ''Wherever you find a bitter, blasphemous Atheist and an enemy of Marriage, Morality, and Social Order,'' The New-York Daily Tribune under Greeley charged, ''there you may be certain of one vote for [the Jacksonians].'' Upon enlisting in the Whig Party in 1835, Representative John Bell of Tennessee sounded like a forerunner of William Bennett, declaring that ''we have, in truth, in the last 8 or 10 years, been in a continual state of moral war.'' Jackson's successor as president, Martin Van Buren, a widower, came in for special abuse as a man of dubious morals, including fantastic Whig charges that he held secret orgies in the White House.
 The Whigs were drawn disproportionately from devotees of the enormous wave of evangelical revivalism known as the Second Great Awakening. Evangelicalism quickly led a minority of Northern Whigs into the crusade against slavery. But mainstream Whigs despised anti-slavery politics and were preoccupied by evangelically inspired efforts to enforce public morality with coercive temperance and Sunday blue-law campaigns. Democrats opposed these efforts, upholding the separation of church and state in order to prevent Congress, one Kentucky Jacksonian wrote, from becoming the ''proper tribunal to determine what are the laws of God.''
 Fate was unkind to the Whig Party. Its first president, Harrison, took sick on his frigid Inauguration Day in 1841, died one month later and was succeeded by a Virginia ex-Democrat, John Tyler, whom some in the party considered to be no Whig at all. The other Whig elected to the presidency, Zachary Taylor, a retired general, lasted only slightly longer than Harrison, felled by an attack of acute gastroenteritis in 1850 after just 16 months in the White House. In between the Tyler and Taylor presidencies, the acquisition of vast Western territories from the war against Mexico led to severe wrangling over the extension of slavery, which neither of the major parties could handle. The Democrats wound up losing their anti-slavery Northern partisans in the 1850's and became dominated by Southern slaveholders. The Whig Party collapsed completely: its anti-slavery wing joined with the Democratic bolters to form the Republican Party in 1854; its Southerners either enlisted in the pro-slavery Democratic fold or floundered in vain attempts to restore sectional comity. 
 The party's sorry demise helps explain why today's Republican conservatives who study history resist any comparison to the Whigs. If they look back before the McKinley era to the 1830's, as Karl Rove has done on occasion, they prefer to liken themselves to the Jacksonians, sticking up for ''the little guy'' against the federal government. But the Jacksonians, unlike conservatives then and now, also battled against the country's financial and mercantile elites and sought to reduce the power of what Jackson called ''associated wealth'' over the nation's economy and politics. Rove's argument distorts the nature of contemporary conservatism's political achievements.
 By lashing Whig principles to Southern states rights dogma, and updating them both, modern conservatives have created a new mutation far more tenacious than the old Whig Party. Invigorating the core Whig tenets about trickle-down opportunity, the Republicans have enriched a plutocracy of Americans unimaginable in the early 19th century and won their financial support as well as their political allegiance. By relying on the Southern version of evangelicalism, stressing personal holiness more than the do-good reformism of Northern evangelical Whigs and enlisting the Christian right in their culture war, they have built a larger and more loyal political base than the Whigs ever enjoyed.
 Of course, today's conservatives shouldn't be complacent about the future of their movement. Bad luck aside, sectional tensions between Northern anti-slavery Whigs and Southern Whig slaveholders finally proved the party's undoing. And even at their high tide, the Whigs had to paper over conflicts between the party's hard-drinking populists and its teetotaling moralists, its moss-backed bluenoses and its more flexible officeholders and party managers. Thurlow Weed's closest political friend, the New York Whig (and later Republican) William Henry Seward, despaired in the early 1840's that ''my principles are too liberal, too philanthropic, if it not be vain to say so, for my party.'' Modern conservatives cope with similar fault lines, including divisions between the old Confederate states and the old Union states, which have placed many ''moderate'' Northern Republicans like Lincoln Chaffee and Christine Todd Whitman at odds with the party's hard-line directorship. 
 And yet modern conservatism has outlived every expectation of its demise. Even today, unsettled by hurricanes, scandals and an increasingly unpopular war, the G.O.P. nonetheless stands for conservative principles and speaks a political language readily understood by voters. Those principles and that language are venerable and, as proclaimed by today's Republicans, more compelling than the confused and uncertain message coming from their opponents. As inadequate, or worse, as the G.O.P.'s privatizing policies may appear, the conservatives' often misunderstood connection to the American past may yet carry them successfully into the future.

HEADLINE: Arguing Against That Deduction

BYLINE: By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
Members of President Bush's Advisory Panel on Tax Reform suggested on Tuesday that the government could pay for the abolition of the alternative minimum tax by cutting one of the holiest of tax deductions: home mortgage interest. 
 The suggestion -- to cap deductions at $300,00 instead of $1 million -- seems like a political nonstarter. But many economists say it would be a good start, questioning how much the deductions have accomplished. 
 Homeowners receive a lot of subsidies. Low-income families can buy their first homes with low-interest loans. There are no taxes on the first $250,000 in capital gains ($500,000 for couples) when properties are sold after two years of residence. Points paid on mortgages are deductible. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two government-sponsored enterprises that buy bundles of mortgages from banks, help consumers win lower interest rates.
 These subsidies support the housing market. People are encouraged to buy a home -- or a bigger home -- rather than purchase other goods and services, invest their money in the markets or set up a business. 
 The mortgage interest deduction influences these choices for some people, but ''if your main goal is to help new homeowners, then you're not getting much bang for your buck,'' said Dwight M. Jaffee, a professor of banking, finance and real estate at the University of California, Berkeley. The subsidy goes only to people who take out mortgages, he explained. And the biggest subsidies go to the people who buy the biggest homes -- the ones who tend to have the least trouble buying a house in the first place.
 Not all economists are against the deduction. Its removal would have ''almost an unambiguous negative impact'' on the housing market and prices, said Douglas G. Duncan, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Association, an industry group that supports the deduction. Consumer dollars might flow into other areas of the economy, he said, but there was no way to know without seeing all the panel's proposals. Moreover, Mr. Duncan pointed out, the advisory panel was required to recognize ''the importance of homeownership.'' Removing the deduction, he said, ''does seem a little bit at odds with the president's statement.'' DANIEL ALTMAN

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 2005

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a presidential panel's suggested changes to the income tax system referred imprecisely to a suggested cap on the home mortgage tax deduction. The panel suggested reducing the size of the mortgage for which interest could be deducted -- to $300,000 from $1 million. The figure would not apply to the deductible interest.

HEADLINE: A Doctor Looks to 2006 With Health Care His Issue

BYLINE: By JULIA C. MEAD

DATELINE: LAKE SUCCESS 

 BODY:
THERE are still 13 months to go before the next gubernatorial election. Is it too soon to be talking about who could be lieutenant governor?
 With the Democratic nomination for governor in 2006 apparently all but sewn up by Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general, at least four candidates are vying for the No.2 spot on his ticket. Two of them are prominent Long Islanders.
That a longtime state assemblyman from Great Neck, an aide to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton or an upstate town supervisor might harbor ambitions for statewide office may come as no great surprise. But a vascular surgeon from Lake Success? 
 Yet Dr. Jon Cohen, the chief medical officer of the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, has come to be seen as one of the two front-runners in the race, if it can be called that so far in advance of the election. And he has done it, by his own admission, as a one-issue candidate: all health care, all the time.
 Dr. Cohen is crisscrossing the state to build support, as is his main rival so far, Leecia Eve, a Harvard-educated lawyer from Buffalo who led Senator Clinton's homeland security advisory team. They have each worked to cultivate party leaders and raise substantial campaign war chests, more than $500,000 for Dr. Cohen and $200,000 for Ms. Eve. 
 But given the history of embarrassingly public clashes between governors and their lieutenants -- George Pataki versus Betsy McCaughey Ross, Hugh Carey versus Mary Anne Krupsak, Mario Cuomo versus Alfred Del Bello -- it is widely expected that the Democratic Party will leave the final choice to Mr. Spitzer.
 ''There will be tremendous deference to his choice, should he decide to make one,'' said Bob Master, a political director at the Communication Workers of America and a co-chairman of the Working Families Party, which usually endorses Democratic candidates for state office. 
 Ryan Toohey, Mr. Spitzer's campaign manager, said Mr. Spitzer had talked with all four hopefuls who have emerged to date: Dr. Cohen, Ms. Eve, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli of Great Neck, and Joseph Ruggiero, the supervisor of the Town of Wappinger in Dutchess County. ''But only incidentally, not in their capacity as candidates,'' Mr. Toohey said. ''It's still early on, and a lot can happen, so we're not really going to comment on specifics right now.''
 Mr. DiNapoli would perhaps have the most at stake if nominated. Dr. Cohen could probably return to his current job if he loses the election, and Ms. Eve has already left Senator Clinton's office, but Mr. DiNapoli would have to relinquish his Assembly seat, committee chairmanships and nearly 20 years' seniority to run for lieutenant governor, raising the possibility of a permanently sidetracked political career if he loses.
 Mr. DiNapoli, who said he had raised $200,000 so far, sounded content to wait for a tap on the shoulder from Mr. Spitzer. The lieutenant governorship ''has no institutional power,'' he said in an interview, ''so whatever influence you'll have in state government will be derived from the strength of your relationship with the governor.''
 Little has been heard from Mr. Ruggiero, except that he, too, is leaving the choice to Mr. Spitzer. But Ms. Eve and Dr. Cohen are taking matters more into their own hands by publicly campaigning for the nomination.
 Ms. Eve, 41, the daughter of a former deputy speaker of the Assembly, stood on the steps of City Hall in Manhattan on Oct. 3, alongside Representative Charles B. Rangel, David Dinkins, the former mayor, and other prominent supporters. The widely publicized moment was meant to position her, a black woman from upstate, as a perfect counterbalance to Mr. Spitzer on the Democratic ticket.
 At that same moment, Dr. Cohen, 51, was in Buffalo, Ms. Eve's hometown, wrapping up a six-county tour by talking with union leaders who were forced to trade away some of their members' pay to maintain health care benefits. Dr. Cohen would not add much diversity to the ticket -- like Mr. Spitzer, he is a white Jewish man from downstate -- but he would come with experience of running a $3.5 billion enterprise, with 16 hospitals, 2 nursing centers and more than 35,000 employees.
 Though it was hardly a headline-grabber, Dr. Cohen's stop in Buffalo was something of a defining moment for him, too. Just as Ms. Eve was listing her priorities as education, job growth, health care and public safety, in that order, Dr. Cohen was hitting his single theme of health care reform again and again. 
 He contends that rising costs and eroding quality of care in the state's health care system are the most pressing problems confronting New Yorkers, and by extension, their next governor. And he wants to be the man the new governor turns to for a solution.
 ''The health care system is dysfunctional at every level,'' Dr. Cohen said. 
 He fires off statistics with machine-gun speed: three million Americans are uninsured, two million of them employed by small businesses that cannot afford to provide coverage; two-thirds of the nation's hospitals lost money last year; 900,000 prescriptions went unfilled in New York last year because patients could not afford the medication. 
 And don't get him started on the prognosis for Medicaid, the government-sponsored insurance program for the poor, whose rising costs are hobbling county budgets across the state. ''What's happening is, there's too little money left for roads, for senior citizen programs and for schools,'' he said.
 Dr. Cohen has not sought public office before, but he is no stranger to the policy debate. He was the senior health care adviser to H. Carl McCall's gubernatorial campaign in 2002, and he helped draft the health care portion of Senator John Kerry's presidential campaign platform. 
 His proposed solution is a plan for universal health-insurance coverage linked to economic development. His mantra is an echo of Senator Kerry's: ''Health care is a right, not a privilege.''
 Dr. Cohen says he favors setting up an insurance pool backed by state-approved private carriers that would spread the economic risks of health care coverage widely and make coverage affordable for small business. At the same time, he said, state-led investment in biotechnology and stem cell research, as California has done, would create jobs and help find cures for diseases that are now medically and fiscally devastating. 
 Covering people who are now uninsured would raise the quality of their care and relieve hospitals of the financial burden of providing it, which cost the North Shore-Long Island Jewish system, the largest hospital group on the Island, some $60 million last year, he said.
 But Mr. DiNapoli sees no precedent for a lieutenant governor becoming a policy maker, the role Dr. Cohen envisions. 
 ''Eliot Spitzer will look first for someone who will be loyal to him,'' Mr. DiNapoli said. The second priority, he added, should be broadening Mr. Spitzer's support beyond his base in the city, preferably with a running mate from the New York City suburbs. ''The swing vote is in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland,'' he said, ''and the resurgence of the Democratic Party in Nassau and Suffolk earns us a place at the table.''
 Peter Stamos, a former adviser to President Clinton and Senator Kerry, said Dr. Cohen's rivals underestimate him at their own risk. 
 Dr. Cohen played a vital role in the merger of North Shore University Hospital and Long Island Jewish Medical Center, two institutions that had been arch-competitors. ''He clearly has excellent business instincts, and an ability to garner support on both sides of the aisle,'' Mr. Stamos said. 
 Mr. McCall, the former state comptroller, said health care's moment as a unifying political issue in the state had arrived, a decade after its spectacular failure on the national level. 
 ''It's now the place where we spend more money in the budget than anything else,'' he said, ''and Medicaid expenditures are creating serious problems in every community in the state.'' Taking a jab at the administration of Governor Pataki, who says he won't run again next year, Mr. McCall said New York lacks any long-term plan to avert a crisis in health care costs.
 ''And I like the idea that someone understands that lieutenant governor could actually be a job,'' he said.
 Mr. Master of the Working Families Party called health care the top priority for labor unions in the election, and said he found Dr. Cohen's ideas fascinating and compelling.
 ''I'm told Verizon will shell out over $20,000 per employee for family health care by end of this year, and that just can't go on,'' he said. ''But no one has ever seen anything like this: a candidate willing to spend the next 13 months talking about the health care system being broken and what needs to be done.''
 Still, he wondered whether the issue was too complicated to resonate with voters now. ''The question is,'' he said, pausing, ''is it better to wait for the governor to address it in a serious way?''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Jon Cohen believes that the lieutenant governor can make a difference. (Photo by Vic DeLucia for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Two Democrats, Road Clears

BYLINE: By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
THE announcement Tuesday that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal would not run for governor in 2006 was welcome news for the two Democrats who have already begun to seek that office. Dannel P. Malloy, the mayor of Stamford, and John DeStefano Jr., the mayor of New Haven, now have two major obstacles: the forces of history and the force of nature currently occupying the governor's seat.
 No mayor in the last 100 years has become governor straight from city hall without first moving on to another office, such as Congress. Howard Reiter, chairman of the Department of Political Science at the University of Connecticut, said mayors carry all the baggage of the state's cities, particularly poverty and racial tension. That distances them from the state's suburban and rural voters.
''The mayor is seen as someone living in an area with very different issues than most of the state is dealing with,'' he said. 
 Meanwhile, Gov. M. Jodi Rell, a Republican, has enjoyed the kind of approval ratings that politicians dream about -- hovering around 80 percent for most of the past year. On Thursday, she filed paperwork to seek her party's nomination, creating a candidate committee that allows her to begin raising money for her election campaign.
 That said, the two Democrats already have a head start in fund-raising over any other candidate, whether Republican or Democrat, and have begun to gain name recognition beyond their cities. On the issues facing the state, they sound similar. Both said job growth was the most important issue, both want to reform the property tax system, and both said Mrs. Rell's $1.3 billion transportation initiative wasn't nearly enough to solve traffic gridlock and mass transit problems.
 Mr. DeStefano likes to tout his working-class roots as a prime reason he would be suited for the governorship. His father was a police officer in New Haven and his mother was a beautician. After graduating from a Catholic high school, Mr. DeStefano went to the University of Connecticut, where he met his wife, Kathy, and eventually earned a master's degree in public administration.
 ''I come from the same kind of family that is typical of Connecticut,'' he said in an interview on Wednesday. ''I understand what it means to get a home equity loan to pay for my kids' tuition.''
 After holding various jobs in City Hall, Mr. DeStefano ran for mayor and lost in 1989. Four years later, he won. He has run New Haven since 1994, a period in which the city has had a large drop in crime, an extensive school construction program, and gradual improvements in student performance. 
 Douglas Rae, a political science professor at Yale University's School of Management, said that when Mr. DeStefano began his first term, he had a chip on his shoulder and couldn't deal with strong people on his staff. He has since relaxed and become nimble at negotiating with powerful institutions, like Yale, which has contributed increasingly to New Haven's tax base despite its tax-exempt status, Mr. Rae said. 
 Mr. DeStefano relishes complicated policy debates. When he talks about cities, he can hardly contain himself, but his concepts can sometimes be difficult to grasp. His sensibility is obviously urban; but if former Gov. John G. Rowland was a Waterbury street-fighter, Mr. DeStefano is more of a professor, the kind who doesn't give out easy A's.
 ''The art of politics and leadership is seeing these issues in their complexity,'' he said.
 Crime has dropped about 50 percent in New Haven since he was elected, Mr. DeStefano said. He gives some of the credit to federal officials who broke up the drug gangs, but also credits the city's community policing initiatives.
 Schools, too, have improved. On the outside, the improvement is obvious. The state has helped funnel more than $1 billion into school construction in New Haven and about 1,700 students from outside the city have chosen to go to school there, Mr. DeStefano said. With some notable exceptions, however, classroom performance continues to lag well behind the rest of the state.
 Mr. DeStefano's record on the economy has been somewhat mixed. Downtown New Haven has experienced a boom as residential developers and restaurants have moved in, and the city has attracted some biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies. But the unemployment rate has risen over the past decade, and the number of jobs has dropped. In 1995, the average unemployment rate in the city was 6.4 percent. Last year, unemployment was up to 7 percent. 
 Mr. DeStefano blames the unemployment numbers on the state, saying that job growth depends on a strong statewide program. 
 Mr. DeStefano's campaign, which has a young and energetic staff run by 23-year-old Shonu Gandhi, leads the fund-raising race, with $2.6 million, as of Tuesday filings. Local newspapers have also pointed out that Mr. DeStefano had taken money from companies and people who do business with the city, particularly on the school construction campaign. He said he has pushed for stronger campaign finance laws, but until they are changed for everyone, he will continue to accept the donations. Mayor Malloy's campaign has also taken money from companies that do business with his city, although he said he would give the money back if the state passes a law creating public financing of campaigns in the next year. 
 Mr. Malloy has received $1.6 million in contributions, and he expected that more wallets will open now after Mr. Blumenthal's announcement. The mayor said support has increasingly come from outside his region. Almost half of his contributors in the last quarter were from outside Fairfield County, according to his campaign office.
 Mr. Malloy, one of eight children, grew up in Stamford, where his father owned an insurance brokerage and his politically active mother organized nurses into a union. 
 In high school, he had already distinguished himself, said Ellen Camhi, the chairwoman of Stamford's Democratic Party. Ms. Camhi met Mr. Malloy when she was on the Board of Education and he was a student liaison to the board. She remembers a speech he made to a room full of adults and policymakers supporting a school lunch program that would allow poor students to get free lunches.
 ''He gave such an incredible speech, a moving speech, it just showed who he is from the start,'' she said. ''I looked at him and said, 'I hope after college you come back to Stamford and run for something.'''
 After graduating from Boston College Law School, Mr. Malloy became a prosecutor with the district attorney's office in Brooklyn. He won 22 out of 23 felony cases there, including four homicide cases, he said. That experience separates him from the other candidates, he said.
 ''I'm the only candidate who has had a law enforcement job,'' Mr. Malloy said in an interview on Wednesday.
 He was first elected mayor in 1995 and has overseen a 63 percent decrease in crime, making Stamford one of the 10 safest cities in the country in each of the past three years, he said.
 Mr. Malloy has sometimes fought with unions. The United Automobile Workers, which represents city workers, has clashed with Mr. Malloy over contracts and benefits over the last few years, even picketing his house over a dispute. Phil Wheeler, a regional U.A.W. official, said Mr. Malloy had been ''terrible'' to work with.
 Chris Cooney, Mr. Malloy's campaign manager, said Mr. Malloy has made numerous ''difficult and challenging decisions'' as mayor, but has formed strong ties with numerous unions.
 Until recently, Mr. DeStefano has also clashed with unions, although he has already received some union endorsements for governor.
 Mr. Malloy has focused heavily on early childhood education, initiating a program that ensures that every 4-year-old in the city has access to nursery school, even if their parents can't pay. Mr. Malloy said he planned to start a similar plan statewide if he becomes governor.
 Mr. Malloy has had some success at improving Stamford's economy and recently announced a plan to bring the Royal Bank of Scotland, one of the largest banks in the world, to the city. Unemployment has dropped from 4.7 percent to 4.1 percent under his leadership and more than 3,000 jobs have been created in the city, according to statistics from the State Department of Labor.
 The Malloy campaign has already survived one major test. A cloud hung over the mayor for months as state investigators looked into his public and private life, probing campaign contributions and improvements made to his house by contractors who had done business with the city. In May, Mr. Malloy was cleared of wrongdoing by Christopher Morano, the chief state's attorney. During the investigation Mr. Malloy stopped holding fund-raisers and lost his initial lead in campaign money to Mr. DeStefano.
 The next big test, however, will be convincing voters that he can govern beyond Stamford. A consultant to his campaign, longtime Democratic operative Roy Occhiogrosso, is already beating that drum.
 ''Being the mayor of a large city is like being the governor of a small state,'' Mr. Occhiogrosso said.

HEADLINE: The Mortgage Maker Vs. The World

BYLINE: By JEFF BAILEY

DATELINE: SIMI VALLEY, Calif. 

 BODY:
A touch of resentment -- based on income, education, social class -- motivates countless ambitious people, though few will admit to it once they become successful.
 An exception is Angelo R. Mozilo, a founder and chief executive of the Countrywide Financial Corporation, a company that has soared from obscurity to become the nation's No.1 mortgage lender -- and, in the process, produced a personal fortune for Mr. Mozilo of about half a billion dollars. This year alone, his compensation is expected to reach $100 million.
Modest origins -- a butcher's son from the Bronx who worked his way through Fordham University -- drove Mr. Mozilo to push Countrywide past the mortgage businesses of far larger companies, including Citigroup, Wells Fargo and Washington Mutual. He readily admits to having a chip on his shoulder, a source of motivation that he has studied, channeled and sought in others, building a company that, too, is an overachiever. 
 The chip also contributes to Mr. Mozilo's feeling that he is entitled to his hefty pay package.
 ''Nobody called me when I was making nothing for years and years and said, 'Can I help?''' Mr. Mozilo said in an interview at a Countrywide loan processing campus that sprawls over a hillside in this Los Angeles exurb, across the road from a garbage dump. His pay, he added, ''is based on my performance.''
 That performance has been impressive, particularly during the recent housing boom. Countrywide's loan volume quintupled over the last five years, and its profit grew even faster, to $2.2 billion last year. But the history of the mortgage industry is full of nasty surprises that sank or slowed once-strong companies -- interest rate swings and frenetic refinancing make the business volatile and risky. That weighs on Countrywide's stock, which trades at a discount to other financial firms.
 On the topic of being underappreciated, Mr. Mozilo doesn't require much encouragement. ''I run into these guys on Wall Street all the time who think they're something special because they went to Ivy League schools,'' he said. For companies like his, ''We're always underestimated. And we still are. I am. I must say, it bothered me when I was younger -- their snobbery and their looking down on us.''
 A lithe, little guy with a jutting jaw, Mr. Mozilo looks like he has faced off against his share of bullies. Today, he dresses elaborately, as if to remind them of who came out on top. A perfectly folded hankie peeks out from the breast pocket of his blue suit; underneath is a crisp banker's shirt in blue with a white collar, and weighty cufflinks with the Countrywide logo. All is set off against a deep tan.
 In an interview, he didn't wait for a question, sallying forth on his own. ''Who I am: I was a messenger boy for a mortgage company in Manhattan,'' he began. ''I was a 14-year-old boy. The people in this company know I did what they're doing. Getting kicked out of real estate offices -- the 40th mortgage guy to walk through the door -- that's the business. It has been a source of strength to me as a leader. Fifty-two years I've been doing this.''
 Mr. Mozilo is 66 and expects to retire at 68. He has recruited others with chips on their own shoulders to carry on at Countrywide after he leaves, and has set them loose on the staid banking industry with something to prove. His top two lieutenants graduated from California State University, Northridge, a decidedly un-Ivy League institution not far from here. Another comes from California State University, Long Beach. All told, the company now employs more than 50,000 people.
 In truth, of course, graduates of less-than-elite colleges are well represented at many large financial institutions. At Wells Fargo, the big San Francisco-based bank, for instance, Richard M. Kovacevich, chief executive and a Stanford man, in August named as his No.2 and apparent successor John G. Stumpf, who has an accounting degree from St. Cloud State University in Minnesota.
 What sets Countrywide apart is the us-versus-them feeling that Mr. Mozilo draws from his life story and his ability to tap into the same feelings in others. Indeed, many of his employees are drawn to what he sells as a free-wheeling meritocracy, and they bring the chips on their shoulders with them.
 ''I did,'' said Brian Hale, who left Wells Fargo four years ago. A Countrywide managing director in charge of retail loan production, he is a graduate of the State University of New York at Plattsburgh. ''In many organizations I compete with, that would disqualify me for the job I have at Countrywide,'' Mr. Hale said of his schooling. True or not, it motivates him.
 ''The key people I depend upon -- that chip is so ingrained,'' Mr. Mozilo said. ''They're sort of my apostles in that regard.''
 The success of Countrywide might cause most executives to let up a bit. The stock has been among the best performers over the last 20 years. Profits exceed $2 billion a year. And, pulling further away from competitors, Countrywide expects to originate between $390 billion and $480 billion in mortgages this year, 14 to 15 percent of the nation's total. Its costs are among the lowest in the industry.
 Countrywide lends directly to consumers and also buys loans from other lenders and from loan brokers. It packages most of the loans up and resells them at a profit.
 Because it is primarily a mortgage lender, however, Countrywide's profits and stock price are vulnerable to interest rate swings, and thus its shares trade for about nine times its per-share earnings, a relatively low multiple. Its nearest competitor in the mortgage business, Wells Fargo, is a diversified bank that is less vulnerable to shifting rates. Its stock trades at about 14 times its earnings.
 Mr. Mozilo bought a bank in 1991 -- its assets doubled over the last year, to $91 billion -- and Countrywide is hanging onto more mortgages, producing a stream of income to smooth the ups and downs of the refinancing market ''so we can get a better multiple for the shareholders,'' Mr. Mozilo said. ''Will we? I don't know. To this day, we are perceived as a proxy on interest rates.''
 While he is sanguine about the stock price, Mr. Mozilo remains volatile about so much else. Particularly irksome are calls by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to shrink Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the quasi-government institutions that buy huge numbers of mortgages from financial institutions, notably from Countrywide. 
 ''Fannie and Freddie are a threat to his banks,'' Mr. Mozilo said of Mr. Greenspan, whose agency regulates big bank holding companies. By buying his mortgages and thus freeing up his capital to solicit even more business, Fannie and Freddie are a big reason Mr. Mozilo has driven Countrywide past the Citigroups and the Wells Fargos to the top of the mortgage heap. ''If it wasn't for them,'' he said of Fannie and Freddie, ''Wells knows they'd have us.''
 He can also be irked by his employees. Walking through a hallway past a worker who is away from his desk and talking on a cellphone, Mr. Mozilo said, ''I hate that.'' The hallways are remarkably empty; workers are in their cubicles, which all have low partitions, so employees can be easily seen. Mr. Mozilo pays less attention to the cubicles' square footage. ''Whether it's smaller or larger, they adapt, like fish to a fish tank,'' Mr. Mozilo said.
 As Anne McCallion, the director of finance, observed, ''Countrywide is not a paternalistic organization.'' Indeed, the company agreed to pay $30 million to settle a lawsuit filed on behalf of employees who say they weren't compensated for overtime.
 The suit and other labor issues are one reason the company now prefers to add workers in Texas and other states with labor laws that are friendlier to employers. Standing beside Mr. Mozilo, Steve Bailey, the chief of loan administration, noted that Countrywide has 17,000 workers in California. ''We should be out of California,'' he said.
 Mr. Mozilo and a partner founded Countrywide in 1969, intent on building the first national mortgage company. After a $3 million stock offering failed, they raised $450,000. By 1983, with more of a track record, they raised $11 million by selling stock, but the deal limited Mr. Mozilo to only small raises to his salary, which was $345,000. The butcher's son had grown accustomed to a good living. ''I had five kids,'' he said. ''It was really hard.''
 As the 1980's wore on, the savings and loan crisis cleared away many of Countrywide's bigger rivals. And the rise of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac allowed Countrywide and others to grow rapidly by selling their loans at a profit and recycling the capital into making new loans. In the refinancing boom of 1993, ''we really came into our own,'' Mr. Mozilo said.
 When boom turned to bust, Countrywide and others laid off workers. And with the likes of Wells Fargo, Citigroup, General Motors Acceptance and other larger companies piling into the national mortgage market, Countrywide briefly considered a takeover offer from Lloyd's Bank about five years ago. But the buyer backed away, Mr. Mozilo said, punctuating the story with, ''Thank God.''
 Around that time, Countrywide invited Eric G. Flamholtz, a consultant and a management professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, to address a strategic planning retreat. When we met, Mr. Flamholtz said, Mr. Mozilo ''gave me a limp handshake.'' But ''when he heard I was from Brooklyn, he perked up.''
 The professor had a wacky notion that the mortgage market, where no lender had more than a 5 percent share, would inevitably and rapidly consolidate, leaving as few as three big players, one of them clearly dominant. He also said pricing wouldn't dictate the winner. ''You win with infrastructure,'' he said. 
 THE prospect of a chance to dominate competitors seemed to reinvigorate Mr. Mozilo. Countrywide invested heavily in technology to lower its costs and quicken its service, then went on to announce a goal to capture 30 percent of the mortgage market. It accelerated the building of a network of 795 local offices to cater to real estate agents and home builders, who refer home buyers to mortgage companies. That network distinguishes Countrywide from competitors that rely more on phone banks. Can Countrywide respond more quickly to homebuilders and homebuyers trying to seal deals? ''Even if I can't,'' said Mr. Hale, who runs retail loan production, ''the perception of the Realtor and builder is I can.''
 The timing was great. Low interest rates led to a huge refinancing boom, which peaked in 2003. Soaring home prices also led consumers to stray in huge numbers from 30-year fixed-rate mortgages to adjustable-rate loans, interest-only loans and, more recently, ''pay-option'' loans that allow payments for a period of time that don't even cover the owed interest, resulting in a rising loan balance, or negative amortization. These mortgages tend to be more profitable than old-style loans. Nonprime loans, those made to less-creditworthy borrowers, brought it nearly four times as big a gross profit -- 3.64 percent of the loan amount compared with 0.93 percent for prime mortgages -- last year.
 But as profits climbed, so did the complexity, and potentially the risk, of Countrywide's operation. Adjustable-rate loans accounted for 51 percent of Countrywide's mortgages last year, up from 14 percent in 2002. In this year's second quarter, pay-option loans, the ones that allow negative amortization, were 21 percent of Countrywide's total, versus just 3 percent a year earlier. 
 That volume of such loans has never been tested in a sharply rising interest-rate environment, a situation feared by some though not yet on the horizon. While Countrywide sells most of its loans, passing the credit risk to others, it had $15 billion worth of pay-option adjustable rate mortgages on its own books at the end of June, and almost one in five of them had experienced negative amortization. If delinquencies on those loans or others rise, Countrywide's ability to sell loans in the future could be damaged. For this reason, Wells Fargo has so far shied away from pay-option mortgages.
 Others aren't as reluctant as Wells Fargo, and fierce competition -- industry overcapacity, really -- has this year squeezed profit margins sharply. In the second quarter, Countrywide's gross profit on loans sold plunged to 1.02 percent of the loan amount from 1.64 percent in the first quarter. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing for the quarter, the company said, ''We believe that industry consolidation should lessen irrational pricing.''
 But is pricing irrational, or is it merely now the norm in a highly efficient industry, one that Countrywide helped develop and one that delivers an abundance of capital to consumers who shop ever more wisely for the best deal? Asked if the thinning of margins will stop, Mr. Mozilo said, ''It's going to ease for the balance of the year.'' But over the long term, ''I don't think so,'' he added.
 Countrywide, like other big financial companies, is diversifying, selling insurance and home equity loans, all in an effort to keep growing and boost profits.
 MR. MOZILO, after pocketing about $70 million last year from salary, bonus and gains on exercising stock options, will probably hit $100 million in pay for 2005. He has already exercised more than three million options, selling the shares, this year. His cash bonus, $17.3 million last year, was the biggest among chief executives of all companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Paul Hodgson of the Corporate Library, a corporate governance organization.
 With huge slugs of options in recent years, and Countrywide's surging stock price ''over the last three years, he has had a $500 million jump in worth,'' said Brian Foley, an independent compensation consultant in White Plains. With shareholders benefiting so, ''you've got to give him his due,'' Mr. Foley said, but added, ''When is enough enough?''
 Countrywide's lead director and chairman of the board's compensation committee, Michael E. Dougherty, chairman of Dougherty Financial Group, a Minneapolis investment company, said of Mr. Mozilo: ''He deserves every penny. He has a passion that only a founder has. I get e-mails time-dated from him at 2 a.m.''
 That's high praise, but Mr. Mozilo is resigned to being underappreciated. When he meets a stranger on the golf course he no longer calls himself a mortgage guy. ''Now I say I run a financial services business,'' he said. ''I don't know why. It makes me feel better. I guess status.'' 
 Before, he added, when he said he was in the mortgage business, ''because of the way I look they say, 'Second mortgages? Sub-prime?'''
