HEADLINE: Picking Up the Pieces

BYLINE: By ANTHONY GOTTLIEB. 
Anthony Gottlieb, the author of ''The Dream of Reason: A History of Philosophy From the Greeks to the Renaissance,'' is the executive editor of The Economist.

 BODY:
POSTWAR
 A History of Europe Since 1945.
 By Tony Judt.
 Illustrated. 878 pp. The Penguin Press. $39.95.
AN old Soviet-era joke, retold by Tony Judt on the next-to-last page of his enormous book ''Postwar,'' is about a phone-in on ''Armenian Radio.'' Is it possible, an eager caller asks, to foretell the future? ''Yes,'' comes the weary answer. ''No problem. We know exactly what the future will be. Our problem is with the past: that keeps changing.'' 
 Sometimes it's hard to believe that just 20 years ago the eastern half of Europe was in the grip of governments so hopelessly incapable of dealing with the present, let alone providing for the future, that only the continual erasure of history could provide them with a semblance of success. With a stroke of the censor's pen, yesterday's disasters never happened.
 But there is also another, more benign way to rewrite history: using hindsight to reveal the past in the light of what it unexpectedly led to. In the darkness of the late 1940's, Europe seemed a shattered continent that was unlikely ever to emerge from the shadow of the giant across the Atlantic. Worse, in the coldest of cold-war years, Europe appeared destined to be no more than a buffer between Washington and Moscow -- either an incandescent graveyard or, if it was lucky, merely a no man's land. How things have changed. 
 The prospect of total war in the West has now receded so far that the darkest visions anyone can plausibly come up with are sporadic bombings by religious youths who think they are refighting the medieval crusades, and modest rises in global average temperatures in the distant future. Compared with the cold war's threat of ''mutually assured destruction,'' this is pretty much scraping the bottom of the barrel as far as apocalyptic visions go. (Even those who fear that terrorists will succeed in using a nuclear bomb must concede that the probability of Armageddon has significantly receded since the cold war.) And Europe is not only at peace; it is thriving. The fast-expanding European Union now binds together some 450 million people who make up the world's largest internal single market. Judt, a prolific British historian who has been teaching at New York University for almost two decades, suggests that ''the 21st century might yet belong to Europe.'' There are some problems with this idea -- more about that later -- but it is in one sense by no means beyond the realm of possibility. As he notes, few could have said such a thing 60 years ago. One of the pleasures of this rich and immensely detailed book is its portrayal of Europe's recovery from the devastation of 1945 as an organic regrowth. What seemed back then to be the twitching limbs of the dying was in fact the stirring of new life.
 As Judt movingly draws it, the picture of Europe at the end of World War II is pitiful almost beyond bearing. Some 36.5 million Europeans are reckoned to have died between 1939 and 1945 because of the war. Tens of millions more were uprooted by Hitler and Stalin. In the immediate aftermath of Germany's defeat, the continent was scarred with violent retribution, purges and outbreaks of what in some places -- like Greece and Yugoslavia -- amounted to civil war. As Judt notes, the war in Europe did not really end in 1945 at all. Neither did the persecution of Jews end with the closing of the death camps: well over a thousand Jews were killed in Polish pogroms after the liberation of Poland. 
 Continuing anti-Semitism in Europe, and the fact that Germany was not always the source of it, is a topic to which the author returns often. While Germany quite rightly bore the brunt of the blame for Europe's tragedy, other villains slipped away unnoticed. It was Austria, after all, that gave the world ''Waldheimer's disease'' -- the inability to remember what you did during the war, named for Kurt Waldheim, a secretary general of the United Nations who became Austria's president in 1986. In a country of under seven million inhabitants, there were still more than 500,000 registered Nazis in Austria at the end of the war. Austrians were greatly overrepresented in the SS and among concentration-camp staff. Tellingly, over 38 percent of the members of the Vienna Philharmonic orchestra were Nazis, compared with just 7 percent of the Berlin Philharmonic. And in an epilogue on modern European memory, Judt reminds us that the sickness that fueled Auschwitz is not fully cured. In 2000, criticizing a study of a wartime massacre of Jews by their Polish neighbors, Lech Walesa, the hero of Poland's anti-Communist uprising and a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, dismissed the study's author as ''a Jew who tries to make money.'' 
 One of the starkest indications of the ''Himalayan'' task facing Europeans in 1945 was the destruction of the housing stock. Germany had lost 40 percent of its homes, Britain 30 percent and France 20. (In Warsaw 90 percent of homes were gone). Under the circumstances, the pace of rebuilding was remarkable, especially in Germany itself. On the day Hitler died, just 10 percent of Germany's railways were functioning; a year later, over 90 percent were up and running. But Europe was starving, and by the start of 1947, every country except Sweden and Switzerland was short of food. 
 The key problems with Europe's economies were the temporary disappearance of Germany as a market for a large part of the rest of the continent's goods, and the lack of hard currency with which to buy food, other materials and goods from America and elsewhere. Britain and France were running out of cash to pay for their imports from the United States, and some other countries did not really have tradable currencies at all. Hungary's inflation, to pick the worst example, was obscene. When its pengo was replaced by the forint in August 1946, the value of all its bank notes in circulation was equivalent to a thousandth of an American cent.
 BY the time George Marshall, the American secretary of state, announced his master rescue plan for Europe in the summer of 1947, the United States had already spent billions of dollars in loans and grants to Europe. But it had not been enough to establish a stable European market for American goods, or to prevent much of the continent from collapsing into -- or so it was feared -- Communism, fascism, anarchy, starvation or all four. Earlier aid had been emergency disaster relief, directed at plugging holes, not at long-term reconstruction. The Marshall Plan was different, and by the time it came to an end in 1952, the United States had disbursed in foreign aid more than all previous American administrations put together. As an equivalent share of America's gross domestic product today, the Marshall Plan would cost around $200 billion. Britain and France got the largest amounts in absolute terms, though the relative impact on smaller countries, including Italy, was greater.
 Britain's foreign minister at the time, Ernest Bevin, rightly called Marshall's announcement of the plan ''one of the greatest speeches in world history.'' But the French, it seems, never quite got it. According to polls in 1950, only one French adult in three admitted to having heard of the plan, and almost two-thirds of those who had said it was bad for their country. Judt argues that the most significant overall effects of America's torrent of money were psychological: the plan helped Europeans to feel better about themselves, and ''it made coordinated economic policy making seem normal rather than unusual.''
 Barely a decade after the end of the war, the engines of Europe's growth were turning as never before. The big Western European countries found themselves in an age of unparalleled affluence and started to mimic American patterns of consumption. Such dramatic change was bound to leave some Europeans in a state of bemused confusion. In 1956, the dyspeptic Jimmy Porter, a character in John Osborne's ''Look Back in Anger,'' sourly noted that ''it's pretty dreary living in the American age -- unless of course you're American.''
 A half-century later, Europeans no longer feel that they are living in an American age, and they -- and many Americans -- are realizing that life may not always be so wonderful even if you are American. Europe now has its own at least superficially attractive social and economic model. Many European countries equal or outperform America in terms of output per hour worked. Europeans tend to have free or cheap medical care, much more generous welfare systems, longer holidays and longer lives. This is a large part of what Judt has in mind when he provocatively argues that it is Europe that now has ''a serviceable model to propose for universal emulation.''
 As he knows, though, there are serious problems looming for Europe. Its aging population is straining its welfare systems, which in some cases are suicidally overgenerous. A far higher proportion of Europeans of working age are economically inactive -- maybe 40 percent, compared with 29 percent in America, according to one study. And Europeans are not having nearly enough babies. By 2050, it is forecast that almost a third of the European Union's population will be 65 or older. America's indigenous population is reproducing too slowly as well, but the United States has what the European Union desperately needs more of: a continuing influx of young and fecund immigrants. 
 Europeans have probably exaggerated the role of their own political arrangements in keeping the peace on the Continent since 1945. Preventing a recurrence of Western Europe's crippling wars, primarily by reconciling France and Germany, was one of the most powerful motives of the first architects of the European Union and its predecessor bodies. But Western Europe was united too by the menace of its common enemy behind the Iron Curtain. And it was America's troops and the threat of its nuclear weapons that helped to keep the overwhelmingly bigger conventional forces of the Warsaw Pact countries at bay, until the Soviet empire's long-suffering subjects realized they had nothing to lose but their chains, and Communism safely and spectacularly self-destructed in 1988-89. It was not America, though, that killed Communism. Judt's detailed, country-by-country account of its suicide is one of the best things in the book.
 A rguably, the finest political achievement of the European Union came afterward, is continuing and lies ahead. The alliance's former game plan of ever-deepening political union among member states probably lies in ruins, now that France and the Netherlands resoundingly rejected its proposed constitution this summer. But the European Union's expansion continues apace, drawing more and more countries -- another 10 joined last year, mainly from the former Soviet bloc -- into a looser form of union. This fosters and cements the spread of liberal democracy by offering membership in exchange for reforms. 
 Turkey is the most recent and potentially most important example. Accepted as a candidate for membership in 1999, it has already increased civilian control over its army, liberalized its justice system and abolished the death penalty, all in the hope of being admitted to the club. The effects of Turkey's possible accession are incalculable and tantalizing to contemplate. If it is allowed in, and present population trends hold their course, then in a few decades the most populous country in the European Union will be Islamic.

 John R. Rifkin)

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 1037 words

HEADLINE: Pluck Be a Lady

BYLINE: By LOUISE JARVIS FLYNN. 
Louise Jarvis Flynn has written about adventure and sports for Women's Sports & Fitness and other magazines.

 BODY:
ADVENTURE DIVAS
 Searching the Globe for a New Kind of Heroine.
 By Holly Morris.
 Illustrated. 283 pp. Villard Books. $23.95.
In her travelogue-cum-quest-memoir, ''Adventure Divas,'' Holly Morris turns her Gen X restlessness into a personal mission. ''Your generation was promised a decent husband and maybe a job on the side, '' Morris tells her mother. ''Mine was promised jet packs.'' 
 Propelled by sporty wanderlust and the soul-crushing routine of a ''pod'' job in publishing, Morris chucked the desk life and staked her career and savings (along with her mother's time and money) on a multimedia pipe dream called Adventure Divas. Mother and daughter planned to seek out intrepid and inspiring women from other cultures -- a folk singer in Tehran, a poet in Cuba, for example -- film their stories, sell the series to a television network and market the whole thing on the Web. Defying the odds, the show ended up on PBS. Morris's account of the experience is a delightful triangulation of adventure travel, telecommuting and self-reinvention that proves it does not, in fact, take a rocket scientist to achieve personal flight.
 From the get-go Morris had two big obstacles: She had never worked in television (she doesn't even own a set), and she needed lots of cash (decent production isn't cheap). Jeannie, her warm and spirited Everymother and a former newscaster, donated $10,000 and her expertise to the project, while Morris found her own solutions by freelancing as ''talent'' for a British company that makes adventure travel documentaries. Her work took her to remote locales with abrasive members of the crew. She became tangled in the learning curve of a new job and endured all kinds of physical hardships -- vicious ''Delhi belly,'' a hotel fire that destroyed most of her belongings. Meanwhile, she passed the hat for Adventure Divas Inc. and e-mailed mom. 
 All this could make for a scattered story line, but Morris, formerly the editorial director of Seal Press, a feminist publishing house in Seattle, cleverly layers her assorted personas and plots. Chapters alternate between her paid television work -- she's sent to the Malaysian jungle, the Swiss Alps and the Sahara -- and her adventure-diva interview trips to Cuba, India, New Zealand and Iran. Morris's self-deprecating wit, sense of pacing and brainy insights into the nature of fear and self-reliance hold the book together. 
 Most of the time the personal, political and professional complement one another nicely, though occasionally Morris overworks her obsession with ''interesting women doing unlikely things in variously oppressive societies,'' and the writing struggles under the weight of its ideological mission. A slog through feminist economics and earnest ruminations on multiculturalism come to mind. There is also one inconsistency that even Morris acknowledges: her plan is to ''seek out 'unsung' folks whose work is driven by personal passion, not 'achievement' status.'' Yet it's hard to see how New Zealand's prime minister, the top female cop in Delhi or a Maori ''pop music icon'' reached career stardom without a hearty pursuit of achievement and an appreciation of status. Frankly, all would probably wonder, what's wrong with a little naked ambition anyway?
 When Morris becomes her own subject the result is always vibrant honesty. ''I have to lay my hands all over something to understand it; burn myself to know it's hot,'' she writes. ''Being in motion, not knowing what's going to happen next, not only suits me, but has become an unlikely vehicle for faith.''
 And she can be hilarious. In Borneo, at a tribal longhouse decorated with shrunken human heads, she slips off to the primitive powder room to apply ''Bobbi Brown's Brillant a Levres Raspberry Shimmer #8 lipstick'' as per her producer's request. She drops her pocket mirror down the squatter toilet hole. Unflappable, she digs in and retrieves the emblem of the beauty myth, knowing full well that the sewer is the very place many Second Wavers would argue it belongs. Morris is a feminist and a realist. Later that same trip, she's lost in the jungle after being separated from the tribesmen who have taken her to hunt wild boar. Oozing from leech bites and contemplating her fate, she realizes she has her period -- and then stares down a five-foot-long snake.
 Obviously, Morris is not afraid to show her everyday self on the page, which is invigorating in a genre that too often has only two speeds: turbo self-aggrandizement and ambling naturalist introspection. The female perspective is also refreshing: how many men could survive not one but two international waxing appointments -- Brazilian and Persian? Certainly not Morris's petulant male companions on the Matterhorn. Throughout the climb they grouse about her as though she were a pal's girlfriend they had to endure for fraternal harmony. Shrugging off their hang-ups, she writes, ''Boys can be so catty.''
 But for all her athletic prowess and pluck, Morris can be as neurotic as the rest of us. The conflict between her inner fears and outer confidence is instantly recognizable to any woman with a good-girl complex. But her solution is cheaper and quicker than a shrink: when she takes on more than she can handle, she retreats mentally to her ''secret happy place . . . under a piece of heavy oak furniture where I mouth to myself, 'You're all alone in this world and the sooner you realize it the better.' ''
 Apparently, this works. Even on her most outlandish adventure -- a caravan through the central Sahara with Tuareg nomads -- she manages to beat back self-doubt. After a week of trudging through the blistering void, navigating by the stars at night and during the day by the angle of the shadows cast by the camels' ears, she arrives at an oasis town. There, a group of veiled men with swords are about to begin a camel race. The reasons for not joining the race are, well, every one you can think of, but Morris gives in to the one reason to do it: ''I want to win.'' When she finishes -- dusting one of the men, by the way -- she is spontaneously engulfed by a crowd of ululating women. She is the first woman ever to have entered the race; an adventure diva is born.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 3; Book Review Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2694 words

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Art

BYLINE: By John Updike. 
John Updike's new book, ''Still Looking: Essays on American Art,'' will be published in November.

 BODY:
NEW ART CITY
 By Jed Perl.
 Illustrated. 641 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. 
 $35.
A hundred pages shorter than Andre Malraux's ''Voices of Silence,'' which surveyed art from its first traces in caves up to the present as of 1953, and a hundred pages longer than Robert Hughes's ''Shock of the New,'' which in 1981 took on modern art from Cezanne to Pop, Op, Happenings and Earthworks, Jed Perl's ''New Art City'' claims on its dust jacket to cover only ''Manhattan at midcentury.'' This is not a coffee-table art book; its illustrations, though numerous, are small, and black-and-white. A dense text rules the textbook-sized pages -- 557 of them, not counting notes, acknowledgments and index. Can there be that much to say about so concentrated a space and span of time? Have no fear: Perl, the art critic for The New Republic, is a fiercely fluent word-spinner, and he comes laden with a staggering knowledge of American artists and their critics from, say, 
 1948, when Willem de Kooning had his first one-man show and Jackson Pollock began to drip in earnest, down to 1982, when Donald Judd began to colonize the flat wilderness of Marfa, Tex., with 100 same-sized aluminum boxes.
 The book could have been called ''Abstract Expressionism and Its Aftermath,'' except that the Abstract Expressionists themselves are given relatively curt treatment, as if the author doesn't dare look at the sun too long. Perl devotes the bulk of his philosophically intricate and aesthetically subtle considerations to the second-generation ''colonizers rather than explorers'' (in B. H. Friedman's paraphrase of W. H. Auden) whose fate it was ''to live in an Age of Silver, or maybe of Lead.'' This book's roll call tends to proceed two by two; it opens with de Kooning and Hans Hofmann, a pair of mature immigrants with an Old World passion for brushed paint, and ends with Fairfield Porter and Donald Judd, an unlikely duo of Silver Age ''empiricists'' -- that is, in Perl's terms, practitioners more concerned with the reality before them than with any romantic role in the historical progression of art styles. 
 The thesis of the book, to be blunt about it, is that art in Manhattan passed in midcentury and beyond from the nighttime creations of existential, heroic, romantic, art-history-minded revolutionaries hardened in the 30's to the daytime works of empirical, eclectic, unheroic, relatively theory-free individualists who had ripened in the shadow of the action-painting giants. These giants are evoked here and there in the book -- Mark Rothko and Barnett Newman toward the end -- and not always in worshipful terms. Pollock, Perl tells us, ''was an artist with a fine-tuned, rather small lyric gift'' graced by a big support system and a ton of publicity; by the end of the 40's ''the technique of dripping or flinging the paint, which Pollock originally borrowed from the Surrealists . . . soon became repetitive, a maze of lines that lock up the canvas all too efficiently.'' Concerning another paint-flinging giant, Franz Kline, Perl admires his famous personal charm and the ''buoyant, open-ended, angst-less void'' expressed by his whites but complains that ''Kline's swaggering black-and-white abstractions can have a perfunctory look -- they suggest a too easily existentialized romanticism.'' Perl's least qualified and most strenuous praise is for such relatively undersung achievements as Joan Mitchell's scrubbily brushed abstractions, Nell Blaine's nearly naive still lifes, Leland Bell's heavily simplified nudes and the obscure Earl Kerkam's worried, often incomplete nudes and self-portraits, expressing ''a quieter kind of yearning'' as opposed to de Kooning's ''gonzo, exhibitionistic romanticism.'' 
 Well, in our anarchic post-Silver age, we are all free to like what we like, and patience with the lesser lights is what an art critic is paid for. Perl's long trek through the Silver Age galleries, however, is a wearying one. His pace enthusiastically picks up with such distinctive artists as David Smith, Joseph Cornell, Alex Katz and the abstract, pre-cartoon-brut Philip Guston, but our overall impression of being buried in an avalanche of reworked art reviews is reinforced by the inclusion of more and more quotation of other critics, at greatest length Harold Rosenberg and Clement Greenberg. Perl prefers the more doctrinaire Greenberg. He accuses Rosenberg of seeming to be ''riffing on Greenberg's ideas, giving his formalist sense of tradition an existentialist zing'' and of composing an essay that is ''all glittering bits -- a hot-air construction.'' 
 While one would not mistake Perl's hip, allusion-rich prose for hot air, it does, in its schematizing ease and eager phrasemaking, attain a warm-air status. As warm air will, it can induce a certain grogginess. ''If oil paint was tradition, collage was revolution, but of course the kind of painting that was done on 10th Street was very much related to the revolution of Cubist collage, and so the connection between painting and collage was complicated, part of the loopy history of modern art'': a sentence like this leads us perilously close to nowhere. Complication goes without saying; we wait for the illuminating generalization. The words ''existential'' and ''empirical'' remain hazy, as much as Perl loves and uses them. The verb ''existentialize'' doesn't exist in my dictionary, and I groped to attach meanings to such nuanced variations of the concept as ''in their wackily existentialist way'' and the report that some Buckminster Fuller domes were sent out ''into the world in a pure, almost existentialized form.'' Almost existentialized -- an unlucky near miss! 
 In his commendable desire to stretch the language of visual perception and philosophical understanding, Perl coins compound adjectives as if hyphens were snowing upon his word processor. We have: ''the individual's at-an-angle relationship with society,'' ''go-with-the-flow neighbors,'' ''an increasingly knit-together, everything-is-one-thing, homogenous character,'' ''knock-you-in-your-teeth actualities,'' ''the wacky-bleak fascination of a play by Samuel Beckett,'' ''this everything-becoming-something-else moment,'' ''more-than-material yet grounded in the materials of art,'' ''the whatever-happens-happens nihilism,'' ''Ashbery's go-with-what-amuses-you attitude,'' and ''the stark, nobody-knows-you-when-you're-down-and-out decrepitude.'' Some of these Germanic compounds, like ''at-an-angle'' and ''go-with-the-flow,'' are handy enough to be used more than once, but they are, along with stretch adverbs like ''amazingly,'' ''infinitely'' and ''immensely,'' and such tenuous concepts as ''everydayness,'' ''brownishness'' and an ''ordinariness'' that ''melts into the silveriness of the images,'' symptomatic of the stresses placed on the vocabulary of those who would write about art. 
 And write about art modern man evidently must. (Full disclosure: I myself have a book of art reviews, infinitely modest, coming out this fall.) The belief that, as the premises of religion and patriotism suffer discredit, an inspiring humanism still lives in the production of paintings and sculpture afflicts us all. Volumes of commentary both precede and follow creative acts. Cezanne and the masters of Impressionism were relatively inarticulate -- their theories spoke in their praxis -- but since then every movement has had its manifestoes, and some of the announced programs, as with the Italian Futurists and English Vorticists, proved more vivid than their visual byproducts. And some, as with Dada, made the denial of art their program. Of the Abstract Expressionists, Pollock and Kline wrote little, but Motherwell and Newman and, most grandiosely, Clyfford Still, wrote and opined much. It is the nature of 20th-century art to cast a dense literary shadow. When one reads, in Perl's last two chapters, of the pungent and aggressive reviews of contemporary shows that Judd and Porter produced for art journals, one wonders if proving themselves as art critics wasn't a way of lending credibility to their own works -- what Perl might describe as the in-your-face-affectless constructions of Judd and the I-paint-what-I-see-and-so-what canvases of Porter.
 If one of the underlying messages of ''New Art City'' is that heroic ''existential'' Abstract Expressionism was something to get over, and another is that an ''empirical'' Silver Age mix of representational and abstract private styles shouldn't be sniffed at, he takes a dark view of the mighty movement that came in between, beloved of collectors and of the nonbuying public alike. Perl sees Pop as the return of Dada, which didn't deserve an encore. Marcel Duchamp -- with Piet Mondrian Manhattan's most dramatic elder in exile -- strikes Perl as a sinister eminence grise. He quotes an article composed by the gallery owners Sidney and Harriet Janis in 1945; it explains of the Frenchman Duchamp, whose American career amounted to little more than a few arresting stunts, that he ''has worked out a system that has produced a new atmosphere in which irony functions like an activating element, causing a pendulum-like oscillation between acceptance and rejection, affirmation and negation, and rendering them both dynamic and productive.'' 
 Perl's comment is uncharacteristically sharp: ''Here, in some carefully chosen words about Duchamp published at the end of World War II, we are face to face with a vision of artistic development as amusingly slippery or ironically aimless that would become commonplace a little more than a decade later. It's a poisonous attitude, so I believe.'' When, in 1958, Dada's deadpan irony was reborn in Jasper Johns's first show, Perl gets personal and nearly nasty:
 ''Johns liked to give his surfaces a beguiling complexity, often with glued-on layers of newspaper. The surfaces were worked over -- worried over. In all of these paintings, there was a suggestion of the collage or the ready-made, for Johns's sensitized surfaces became a mocking echo of the pancake-flat object -- a flag or a target or a map -- that he had taken as his subject. He used his slurpy encaustic paint to make painterly love to his quotidian subjects. He was slumming -- oh so elegantly.'' 
 Irony, mockery -- these are poisonous, presumably to the health of the humanistic enterprise, diminishing ''the grandeur of art'' so that it ''was no longer a force that by pushing artists forward granted them their freedom.'' Johns's painstaking technique of encaustic over collage is ''slurpy,'' an image that becomes, in ''painterly love,'' curiously sexual. The critic tells us what Johns likes, and when he is slumming. He does not entertain the possibility that the famous flags and targets and maps were a way of coping with the chronic modernist issues of representation and reality, central to the surreal puns of Max Ernst and Magritte and Dali. And yet in other instances Perl grants artists the freedom to do what feels right, to let each work be ''an attempt to give form a shape that matched the artist's emotion.'' The concomitant obligation is to avoid doing what doesn't feel right, and Johns, with many in his generation, avoided trying to redo the great deeds of Western art, including the flamboyant gestures of the Abstract Expressionists. An image that is also a thing -- a flag or target or map -- is one way to subdue Expressionism while keeping painterliness.
 Pop was a counterrevolution that made art experts feel, as Leo Steinberg admitted, like philistines. Perl quotes with zesty approval Fairfield Porter's disparaging review of a Johns retrospective in 1964, as displaying ''the course of an education that has been carried out in public.'' Porter went on, ''It shows the reaction to his education of an individual intelligent enough at first to take in all that he is being taught while giving it only part of his attention.'' Perl adds, ''And so Jasper Johns went straight to the top of the class.'' Usually noncombative, Perl on Pop takes sides all over the place; Leo Steinberg, quoted on Johns as an ally, is guilty of ''an avant-garde softheadedness'' when he tries to find something good to say about Robert Rauschenberg's enigmatic combines: ''What he liked about Rauschenberg's work was the mushy meanderings that the combines kicked off in his mind.'' 
 As for Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol, they are understood as deft perpetrators of implicitly fraudulent effects: Lichtenstein's blown-up comic strips won acceptance because ''they were susceptible to a kind of formalist, Bauhaus-inspired analysis that had been familiar at least since the 1940's,'' and Warhol, who left doing shoe advertisements to imitate Lichtenstein's big cartoons, happened, in his factory of duplication, on ''one Pop subject that had an immediate, visceral appeal for a sophisticated (and even for an intellectual) audience: the movies.'' Cleverly concentrating on stars associated with intellectuals like Arthur Miller and Richard Burton, he ''presented gallerygoers with a Hollywood universe in which just about everybody had at one time or another found a fantasy of romantic involvement. The whole arrangement worked beautifully for the part of the audience that wasn't interested in heterosexual sex.'' The little sting in this last phrase brings us to the matter of ''sophisticated campy taste'' that flavors the Pop movement; many if not most of the name artists were homosexual, and an ''at-an-angle'' derision of the straight world blinds Perl, it seems to me, to the innocence of Pop's basic appeal; as with Norman Rockwell's Post covers, the public recognized elements of the world it lived in. Claes Oldenburg, who wound up designing drolly huge public monuments, began, in 1961, with ''The Store,'' a mock emporium located in a working-class district where the East Village met the Lower East Side, stocked with grungy, brightly and messily enameled plaster replicas of merchandise -- candy bars, men's suits, pastries, corsets -- redolent of the 1940's. Perl offers an sour epigram: ''An art without a will of its own was an art drifting into nostalgia -- that was always the condition of Pop.'' 
 The Pop episode prompts the sole deviation from Perl's ''what-happens-happens,'' ''go-with-what-amuses-you'' survey. He is as fondly respectful of Cornell's fey little boxes of assemblage as he is affronted by Rauschenberg's brut combines, and Judd's artifacts, which might seem as impudently blank as Johns's flags, are cherished for the aesthetic values they bring over from the industrial world: his plywood boxes ''were about the beauty of plywood, its color, its patterning, its edges with their sandwiched layers.'' No Dada urinals, snow shovels or bottle racks need apply, without those buzz-sawed, sandwiched layers.
 The book's title and subtitle lead a reader to expect more concrete speculation as to why New York, which after all didn't lack bohemian strivers prior to 1945, replaced Paris as the world's art capital. One reason is perhaps too obvious for Perl to dwell on: the city was the economic capital of the only major combatant nation to emerge from World War II with its infrastructure intact and its civilian population unharmed. The private wealth of the postwar boom was a more flexible and lavish patron than the government's Depression mural projects could be. The expanding size of the Abstract Expressionist canvases, an index of their ambition and their strategy of engulfing the viewer, related to the size of the cheap lofts being vacated by downtown Manhattan's declining industries. The bold splashes found receptive pale walls in the rising skyscraper city, its swell midtown apartments and its newly fashionable museums. Downtown abounded in cheap living, found art, permissive cafeterias and jazzed-up friends. An Englishman, Cyril Connolly, in Horizon in 1947, said it best: New York presented ''an unforgettable picture of what a city ought to be: that is, continuously insolent and alive, a place where one can buy a book or meet a friend at any hour of the day or night.'' He promised, ''Something important is about to happen.'' Who feels that now?

HEADLINE: City Planner Manque Still Thinks Tall

BYLINE: By DAVID COLMAN

 BODY:
EVEN the most painstakingly accurate map is at heart a phony. It presents itself as passive, just attempting to define, to delineate. Meanwhile it is furtively, actively striving to corral with boundaries, crisscross with roads, create with lines.
 Visitors to the storied Restaurant Florent in the meatpacking district of Manhattan might not grasp such lofty fine points from the maps lining the bistro's walls. Since the city names are obscured (Is that Rotterdam?), it's tough to grasp anything about them at all. 
A suite of maps in the SoHo apartment of Florent Morellet, the bistro's owner, is even more baffling. With nothing more than the sinuous contours of the Seine in common, the six maps are actually fantasy metropolises: one in the Midwestern United States, one in central Africa, one of Paris after World War III. They were meticulously created in obsessive-compulsive fits by Mr. Morellet, who has been poring over maps since he was a child in Paris.
 But a career in city planning, briefly envisioned when he was studying at Central London Polytechnic in the early 1970's, was not to be. ''Fourteen of the 15 students were very P.C. and green and anti-skyscraper,'' he recalled. ''And here I was, who thought that Paris was boring, too flat.'' His proposition that there should be a skyscraper at each of Paris's great radial intersections was not met with open arms. 
 In 1978 Mr. Morellet fled Europe for Skyscraper Central and has been content ever since. He even did a little city planning, opening Florent 20 years ago in what was then a fringe neighborhood known for meat carcasses and leather bars. It reminded him of Les Halles, the Parisian late-night marketplace, which was famously demolished in the 70's and replaced with what he calls ''one of the worst urban renewal projects in the world.''
 With the ghost of Les Halles in mind, it makes sense that he would spearhead efforts to protect the low-rise meatpacking district and the derelict High Line viaduct adjacent to it. Still, he is torn at having gone to court in 2002 to stop a tower designed by Jean Nouvel, his countryman, from going up a block from his restaurant.
 ''I've found myself fighting the fabulous skyscrapers I love,'' Mr. Morellet said resignedly of his odd local-hero status. On Saturday a benefit to preserve the district and the viaduct is to be given in his honor at the nightclub Roxy. ''A city should have mountains, but it should have valleys as well.''
 So his favorite possession is somewhat ironic, or at least made of iron. It is an antique model of the Flatiron Building, the 1902 tower that went up at the intersection of 23rd Street, Fifth Avenue and Broadway, then a major crossroads. Its revolutionary steel frame wrapped with a curtain wall of limestone changed skyscraper construction forever.
 The Flatiron's place in history may be the reason the eight-and-a-quarter-inch model cost so much -- almost $800 -- in the 80's at the vintage-design shop Lost City Arts. But its importance is not what interests Mr. Morellet. 
 ''I love it because it's absurd,'' he said. ''It's the great folly of location, location, location. Economically it doesn't seem to make sense, all those weirdly shaped triangular floors.'' But its site and odd shape mean that as you come down Fifth Avenue you can experience the full 20 stories head on, which is the case of almost no other skyscraper. ''It's so beautiful,'' he said.
 The model harks back not just to Mr. Morellet's childhood love of making tall buildings from Legos but also to the early-20th-century youth of the skyscraper, to what now seems a simpler time, when buildings and the future all seemed to be looking up.
 But then, the future seems always to have looked brighter in the past. The trick is to appreciate the two, yet manage to live in the present. There ought to be a map.

HEADLINE: See Daddy Make a Deal

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
A few weeks ago Nick Richardson, a writer of marketing materials who lives in Manhattan, took his oldest daughter, Emma, 6, to the birthday party of one of her former classmates. While he was chatting with another father -- someone Mr. Richardson had known since their children were at nursery school -- the other man mentioned that the advertising agency where he worked had won a major account. It would mean taking on new talent. Would Mr. Richardson be interested, the man asked, in having his name put forward for a job, adding persuasively, ''I think you would fit in perfectly.''
 For generations private schools have nurtured connections among the privileged, but the bonds were most likely to form among students, who carried their old school ties into business and the professions after graduation. Except for occasional meet-the-teachers evenings or concerts, parents spent little time at schools. But now in an age when parents are closely, even obsessively, involved in their children's lives, school activities have multiplied to include lectures on parenthood, ''take a parent to school'' days, science fairs, field days, parent breakfasts, sports dinners and spring auctions, all of which draw parents ever more closely together. 
''They now see each other all the time,'' said Howard Greene, an educational consultant in Westport, Conn., and New York City, who advises families about private schools. Doing business together ''becomes a natural extension of the deep friendships that grow from a base of personal trust, shared values and a shared destiny,'' he said. 
 Mr. Greene himself found a publisher when a fellow trustee of one of his four children's schools turned out to be interested in the education books he wrote.
 The newest world of business networking is therefore not the golf course, the power breakfast or the alumni reunion. It is the schoolhouse. As much as country clubs once did, schools -- especially private day schools -- are bringing together professionals and high-powered executives in a clubby atmosphere of mutual trust that some are finding particularly conducive to deal making. While school administrators can find the trend vexatious and erect barriers to prevent it, like forbidding the use of school directories for soliciting business, many parents discover school contacts are too priceless to ignore. 
 School officials say parents rarely go so far as to select a school just to rub a particularly influential set of elbows. ''We ask that our parents check adult agendas at the gate,'' said Timothy R. Bazemore, the headmaster of New Canaan Country School in Connecticut. ''Our parents understand that and agree.'' But what happens later, below the school radar, is probably inevitable, the same officials say.
 It is not, however, always benign. Jim Skrumbis, the headof school for Grades 9 through 12 at Sierra Canyon School in Chatsworth, Calif., and formerly a senior administrator at two other private schools in Los Angeles, recalled how a school-hatched business deal led to trouble. 
 ''There was this guy who was an inventor,'' he said, ''and he got in close with another parent, who put up some money for a special kind of golf club that was supposed to be big.'' The club succeeded, but the men joined in other investments that ran into financial troubles. They had a falling out, charges flew back and forth, and they ended up in litigation. The animosity between their families spilled over into their encounters at school. Other parents took sides, and Mr. Skrumbis had to mediate to keep peace. ''It can become uncomfortable both for the students, the parents and the school,'' he said.
 A major change propelling the trend, school officials say, has been the wave of involved fathers. Even a decade ago fathers wrote tuition checks but rarely participated in school life. Today ''you see far more dads volunteering for all sorts of things,'' said Bernice Hauser, the director of intercampus activities at Horace Mann School in Riverdale, the Bronx.
 Then there are the many mothers with careers. Their conversations in school hallways, auditoriums and conference rooms gravitate toward professional concerns. ''It has evolved as women's lives have changed,'' said Laura Lopata, who is married to Mr. Richardson, the marketing writer. Ms. Lopata is the president of Accent on Image, a small firm that coaches executives in interpersonal skills. She said she has several potential clients who can be traced to her school contacts.
 Professional networking is found in public schools, too, although it seems less common. Lance Wolfson of Brookville, N.Y., for example, says he has gained half a dozen customers for his commercial packaging business from fathers at local public schools, which three of his four children attend. Yet he has noticed better networking at the private school where his youngest son has just enrolled. After only six weeks Mr. Wolfson has picked up two new customers there.
 Other parents with children in both public and private schools observed that public school parents are more likely to leave business at the schoolhouse door. They note that public schools are typically larger, students' families have a wider range of incomes and, perhaps most important, public schools do not have the clubhouse mentality of private schools -- the result of winning admission, steep tuition and social homogeneity. 
 Private schools also tap parents to help in capital fund drives, introducing a climate of business into the life of the school. ''There is usually a development person at each private school who actively recruits the fathers for this sort of work,'' said Helene Abramson of Princeton, N.J., whose four children have attended a mix of public and private schools. And the friendships that ensue more easily lead to business dealings.
 Fund-raising is done in public schools, too, but often limited to raising money for activities not covered by the school budget, like outside speakers or buses for team sports. And parents say these fund-raisers are more likely to be led by at-home mothers. Mrs. Abramson, who worked on auctions for her children's public schools, said, ''I only remember one father being part of our committee in all the three years I was active.''
 The business networking at public schools is lower key, said Ellen Gefen of Greensboro, N.C., whose children have attended both public and private schools. It is more likely, she said, among ''the moms with a small home-based business looking for help, or a life-style issue such as using a parent who is also a doctor.'' 
 School connections have led to whole new businesses. Colleen Ambrose, a mother of four children who attended New York private schools, said that her fashion line, Courtney Vaughan, which makes dresses for 10- to 14-year-olds, developed from school contacts. She met her partner, Brigid Merriman, 19 years ago when their daughters were in preschool. After seeing how difficult it was to find formal dresses for preteenagers, they started their business, now eight years old. 
 Similarly, George Birnbaum, a lawyer specializing in commercial and employment litigation, gained clients through contacts he made when his two daughters attended New Canaan Country School and Greenwich Academy in Connecticut. 
 ''There is no question that I have come in contact with some very powerful business people,'' said Mr. Birnbaum, a partner in Minogue Birnbaum. ''They get to judge you as a person when they see you with your children. And that makes them more comfortable. Would I have known them otherwise? I really don't know.''
 The parents have reason to trust one another. ''You think to yourself, 'You're not going to steer me wrong because we will have to face each other time and again over the next few years,''' said Cindy Morriss, a parent volunteer at St. Stephen's Episcopal School in Austin, Tex. 
 Private schools, aware of their responsibility to safeguard the privacy of families, some of whom pay $20,000 or more for tuition each year, have strict policies against putting school directories to business uses. The disclaimer posted in the 2005-6 parents' association directory of Marymount School in Manhattan, is typical: ''For reasons of privacy and safety, it is school policy not to give out the parents/student list to anyone for commercial purposes, nor to allow the use of the address lists by anyone within the Marymount community for solicitation or any commercial purpose.''
 At St. Luke's School in Greenwich Village a prohibition against using school lists for marketing or business is written into the handbook parents receive when their children are enrolled, said Ann Mellow, the head of school. Some schools limit their directory to the class list, said Victoria Goldman, the author of the newest edition of ''The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools and Selective Public Schools.'' 
 ''We need a giant stop sign placed in front of parents who think they can use the school directory or even the class list as a surfing opportunity for their business interests,'' Ms. Goldman said. ''I absolutely think it's gauche, inappropriate and opportunistic.'' 
 Yet school networking rarely takes the form of exploitation of telephone and address lists. It is usually much more subtle. Monica Longworth, who has two children who have attended private school in Manhattan, said it is easy to discern the line between forming a friendship that later blossoms into a business relationship and ''developing a personal relationship solely for business purposes.'' An example of the first, she said, is her friendship with a mother at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Day School when their daughters were in preschool there. The woman still refers clients to her marketing consulting business.
 On the other hand Ms. Longworth recalls one father, an insurance salesman who had a son in her son's school, who telephoned repeatedly to invite her husband to socialize outside school. As they had never been particularly friendly in school, his motives seemed all too clear.
 And then there are school administrators who like the idea of business contacts among parents, reasoning that they can even be good for the school. ''It can work wonders for development,'' said Nicholas Thacher, who has been working as a head of private day schools for more than 30 years, most recently as the interim head of Dedham Country Day School in Massachusetts. ''Parents will see it as a legitimate way to contact peers and at the same time learn about shared business interests.''
 Ultimately these schools could benefit from the trend. As a result they may come to view business networking with less trepidation. Besides, ''it's going to happen anyhow,'' observed Ms. Gefen, echoing a widely held view among parents.

HEADLINE: Final Stages

BYLINE: By William Goldstein. 
William Goldstein, a member of the American Federation of Musicians, has composed scores for films and musicals.

 BODY:
AS the new theater season opens, Broadway has a serious problem that threatens its very existence. 
 Sure, grosses have never been higher and audiences last season were the largest in the last 20 years, but the number of actors and musicians working on Broadway is way down. Today, there are 75 percent fewer actors and musicians employed than in the 1940's. Back then, 88 shows, on average, opened per season (double the number produced today), and musicals had 40 to 60 actors on stage and 26 to 50 musicians in the pit.
Production costs are out of control. A musical that cost $300,000 to produce 50 years ago costs close to $10 million today. And a play that was produced for $75,000 in 1944 would now cost about $2 million. Even after accounting for inflation, today's costs are as much as 4.5 times greater than they were half a century ago. While production costs are about 33 times higher than they were in the 1940's, ticket prices are only about 14.5 times higher. As a result, a show that 50 years ago might have paid off its backers after three months now needs to run for nearly two years to break even. 
 These costs are keeping producers from taking risks. In the 40's and 50's, a single person could produce a play; now it takes a half-dozen and corporate backing. Thus, nearly half as many plays are produced. 
 If this trend continues, it could spell the end of New York as the home of one of America's great cultural contributions, the Broadway show. Some are already suggesting that Las Vegas is becoming the new theater capital.
 So, what's the answer? 
 Sadly, there's no easy solution, but here are some suggestions that could economically revitalize Broadway. For starters, the city could help. New York gives tax breaks to large employers to keep them in the city. Why not offer similar tax breaks to Broadway? 
 The city could set aside part of property tax revenue from theaters, and start a fund available to Broadway productions during their run. The fund could aid shows struggling to find an audience by kicking in when low box office revenues lead to the waiving of royalty payments (that percentage of weekly gross paid to the show's creators). The fund would lend at zero percent interest, up to 50 percent of a show's operating cost for up to four weeks. If the show recovers, the money would be returned to the fund.
 And there's more we could do. The challenge, of course, is to lower costs, stimulate more productions, put more performers to work and still maintain a respectable wage. These goals could be achieved if all the people involved in putting on a show were willing to share in the risks and rewards.
 Union leaders could begin a hire-more-actors-and-musicians campaign. Instead of trying to get higher salaries and benefits for the fewer and fewer actors and musicians working on Broadway, union leaders could make it their goal to get more people working. This could be achieved by having union leaders and producers agree on a sliding salary scale based on the number of performers employed. 
 The more actors or musicians hired, the lower the scale. At 40 actors or musicians, the lowest pay scale would be reached. When a show is in trouble and royalties are waived, actors and musicians would be required to work at half their salary for up to 60 days or until the show returns to profitability. The stagehands union could agree to a similar program.
 On a hit show, producers would pay bonuses to all performers and stagehands above current scale. These bonuses could come from a predetermined percentage of the show's profits.
 This strategy would keep more shows open and more people working. In comparison to the writers who spend years creating shows with no income until their show is produced, these are small sacrifices for actors and musicians to make for the greater good.
 Theater owners occasionally reduce theater rentals when the show's creators and producers waive all royalties. This should become the norm. 
 And the news media could help, too. Reviews could be opened up to include commentary by people who are not professional critics. In literary reviews, authors and experts, not just professional critics, assess books. This healthy infusion of ideas would go a long way toward balancing the near stranglehold that professional critics wield over the theater. 
 Working together, politicians, union leaders, producers, actors, musicians, theater owners and the news media can revitalize Broadway, enabling producers to recreate the golden years of New York theater by putting on magical shows with large casts and orchestras and opening the door to new successes that will become tomorrow's classics. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Lights Out

BYLINE: By JEFF VANDAM

 BODY:
THE old man in the khaki pants, white high-tops and navy windbreaker crooned a tune of his own composition as he wandered slowly down Buffalo Avenue past a green sedan held together with duct tape.

 What you say
 What you gonna doooooo --
 They gonna close the hospital.

 A smiling figure in a black sweatshirt called out to him. ''Hey, you better have good health insurance.'' 
 Without turning his head, the singer continued his ambling toward nowhere in particular. ''Man, I been coming here since Bush was president, the first Bush,'' he remarked. ''But I got the same coverage as Bush, man.'' 
This was a joke, and his audience, the handful of people hanging out in front of St. Mary's Hospital, laughed, but not much. Rather, the mood on this shabby street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was elegiac, almost melancholy. As nurses in crisp white uniforms exited the building on Sept. 30, the Friday of their last full work week, people who were gathered on the sidewalk called out affectionately to them, ''Take care, baby.'' 
 The hospital, a concrete and glass colossus emblazoned with enormous metal crosses that sits a few blocks north of Eastern Parkway, was preparing to close out a century and a quarter of service to its neighborhood. A 241-bed Roman Catholic institution that laid its cornerstone on this blocklong site in 1879, it had long served as the neighborhood's pulse, albeit an increasingly weak one. Now, the hospital having run out of money, the pulse barely registered. 
 Although inpatient services were scheduled to end officially on Oct. 4, the hospital building was already nearly empty. In the emergency room, where lines of people used to wait to register, a single nurse sat at a desk, a few paperback copies of Lippincott's drug guides stacked haphazardly on the counter. No one waited in the waiting room, its magazines sat unread, and ''A Current Affair'' unwatched on the television set. In the examining rooms, X-ray machines poised over tables pointed down at -- nobody.
 The hospital's parent organization, St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, had filed for bankruptcy protection in July, following years of growing debts -- currently more than $1 billion -- and declining revenues. By the end, St. Vincent concluded, there was no financially feasible way to keep St. Mary's open. It had lost money as if through a sieve, and in the past few years, lost wards-full of patients.
 Statistics tell the story. Since 1999, the first year St. Vincent began keeping data on St. Mary's, inpatient occupancy had hovered at unsustainable levels -- in other words, not enough patients to pay the bills. In 2004, the portion of beds filled by inpatients had dropped to 57 percent, down from a recent high of 64 percent in 2002, still not enough in its own right to make ends meet. The hospital was losing $10 million a year, and a range of factors -- better technology, fewer surgical cases, less violent crime, a pronounced drop in AIDS-related admissions -- had meant fewer patients and shorter stays at St. Mary's.
 Local hospitals are not necessarily a city's best hospitals, but they are often among the most cherished, especially in the low-income neighborhoods where so many of them are. In these communities, having a local hospital is a little like having a family doctor nearby. You can walk to their clinics and emergency rooms, and when you arrive, the faces of the nurses and the doctors, even the faces of the people at the desk, are familiar. If there's an emergency, it's comforting to know that some sort of medical care is close at hand. 
 Like the local library, the local movie theater and the local playground, they are part of the glue that binds neighborhoods together. But with the growth of mega-institutions, and medical economics having grown ever more complex and unforgiving, such glue is in increasingly short supply.

An Ambulance at a Fast Trot
 The message posted on the hospital's entrance was clear and without detail: ''It is with deep regret that we announce the closing of St. Mary's Hospital Brooklyn effective October 4.'' Those needing immediate help were told to contact Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center, a private hospital a mile away in East Flatbush that was to take over management of six of St. Mary's seven clinics.
 The message brought a curt end to a formidable past. Here, for more than a century, residents flocked to the emergency room -- in decades past for diseases like influenza, smallpox and polio, in more recent years for asthma, diabetes and AIDS-related illnesses. Even in the hospital's last weeks, a gallery of St. Mary's past still hung on the wall in the front hallway, black-framed photographs that traced the institution's role as a beacon of the community.
 The most noticeable elements in the photos were the nuns who supplemented the medical staff: nuns with patients, nuns with doctors, nuns performing experiments in a lab. They looked caring, as did the other hospital workers whose images lined the wall. In one photo, smiling, newly certified nurses posed in a sort of chorus line; in another they flanked a 100-year-old man, grinning gleefully as he held a sign commemorating his birthday.
 The hospital's history and its relationship with Crown Heights come alive in these pictures. But in reality, St. Mary's was born in a modest building four miles away.
 In 1867, a tiny house at Congress and Clinton Streets in Cobble Hill became the first St. Mary's, guided by John Loughlin, the Bishop of Brooklyn. Called St. Mary's Female Hospital, it was managed by four nuns who are said to have been so keen to begin their duties that they ate their first meal standing up and using borrowed dishes.
 With money raised by the hospital's Ladies Aid Association, the institution soon moved a few blocks away to roomier quarters on Dean Street, but those, too, were not enough for Bishop Loughlin, who was concerned especially about the number of children in the infants' ward. He then selected another site, a blocklong plot farther out in Brooklyn just north of the recently completed Eastern Parkway, where he hoped to build a true general hospital. 
 That neighborhood, known as Crown Heights, had been growing, made enticing by the promenades and carriage paths of the broad, tree-lined parkway. Home to some of New York's earliest free black settlements, Crown Heights was seen by the gentry as the appropriate setting for their new mansions, and slightly less affluent New Yorkers had begun taking up residence in brick and limestone row houses sprouting up in the area.
 In October 1879, construction began on the new St. Mary's, on a block bounded by St. Marks Avenue, Prospect Place, and Buffalo and Rochester Avenues. The results, completed in 1882, were impressive: an elegant brick Second Empire-style complex with gardens, trees and wrought-iron fences housing eight wards, 50 private rooms and, starting in 1883, ambulance service, provided by a dashing horse-drawn carriage.
 For nearly a century, St. Mary's stood as a center of progress. A nursing school opened in the early 1900's; schools of medical and X-ray technology arrived at midcentury. As the hospital acquired more patients, more medical students and more prestige, construction began in 1976 on a new building, a $38 million tower that a hospital fact sheet described as ''ultra-modern.'' At the time, it seemed the only direction St. Mary's could go was up.

The E.R. on the Corner
 When the newest St. Mary's officially opened on Feb. 17, 1979, Katrina McCloud, 6 years old and suffering from rheumatoid arthritis in her right knee, was one of its first patients. 
 ''Everything was new; we were really moving into a new era,'' said Ms. McCloud,a cheerful 32-year-old with round cheeks and a beaming smile. Today, she and her 56-year-old mother, Harriet, share a two-bedroom apartment on Prospect Place, exactly one block from St. Mary's emergency room; the two have never lived more than a few blocks from the hospital.
 It rained the day young Katrina first stepped inside the new building, but despite the weather, the sense of possibility seemed almost tangible. The hospital featured a gleaming emergency room, new beds, new medical equipment, and only the best in aesthetic design. ''The motif has been balanced in a very natural tradition of bright and lively colors so that patients and visitors experience a warm and comfortable feeling at St. Mary's,'' the hospital fact sheet said. The hope, of course, was that the new St. Mary's would last as long as its venerable predecessor.
 But the hospital experienced considerable change over the next two decades, as did the neighborhood around it. No longer did the rich saunter down Eastern Parkway in top hats; now, the hats were more likely to belong to the large population of Hasidic Jews who moved to the area in the first half of the 20th century. The other main ethnic group was African-Americans, largely of Caribbean descent; in 1991, their clash with their Jewish neighbors exploded in violence that redefined politics and social relations in New York. This second group, a low-income population highly dependent on Medicare and Medicaid, has provided most of the hospital's patients in recent decades.
 Harriet McCloud's mother is one of those patients. Her lined, gaunt face makes her look much older than her years, and because she is frail and cannot walk well, she needs a wheelchair to get around. She has lost sight in one eye, which she squints so much it is almost closed. She also suffers from myriad ailments -- congestive heart failure, kidney failure, hypertension, diabetes -- that have made regular trips to the emergency room a sad family tradition. Her health problems have worsened over the years, so much so that they have come to dominate both her life and her daughter's. 
 ''My mom,'' Ms. McCloud said, ''is a sick woman.'' 

A Fragile Fabric of Care
 Like so many urban hospitals, in New York and beyond, St. Mary's died a slow death. 
 Overwhelmingly, hospitals that have closed their doors have been in minority areas like Crown Heights that have also lost a number of private medical practices. (A state-sponsored group, the Berger Commission, is currently studying ways to ''right-size'' New York's hospital industry, prompting fears of more such closures.) The result is an overburdened institution and an acute lack of local doctors, bringing down the overall level of medical care available in the area.
 ''It's a little bit like a well-maintained car with a good motor and new wheels, but no transmission,'' said Alan Sager, director of the Health Reform Program at Boston University, a policy study group. 
 For 30 years, Dr. Sager has tracked national hospital closings and other indexes of health care, and his numbers suggest a domino effect, one in which patients displaced by one hospital take costly multiple diagnoses to the next closest one, putting added stress on its resources, and so on. In the northeast section of Brooklyn, where St. Mary's is, 27 hospitals (not counting St. Mary's) providing a total of 3,689 beds have closed since 1936.
 For patients, many of whom who have spent years cultivating relationships with doctors and nurses at a specific hospital, the problems can be daunting. As Dr. Sager put it, ''That fabric of care, once it's shredded or torn by the closing of a hospital, is very hard to reweave.''
 In the last few years, St. Mary's saw both its revenues and its patient population drop with alarming speed. Last May alone, the hospital, with an annual budget of $134 million, lost $3.8 million, and the percentage of occupied beds had decreased sharply.
 According to St. Vincent, the operating losses, combined with a lack of money to make needed improvements, made closing the institution the last but only choice. A year earlier, St. Vincent had begun negotiations to transfer operational control of St. Mary's to Kingsbrook Healthcare System, but the deal fell through; the $10 million per year required just to cover St. Mary's losses proved too great a sum. 
 Over the summer, as the transfer moved through bankruptcy court, Crown Heights residents held their collective breath. Early last month, St. Vincent received permission from the court to close the hospital and set a date: Oct. 4 of this year, 138 years after Bishop Loughlin opened the first St. Mary's.
 Even now, the fate of the hospital building is unclear. All that is known is that its ambulatory care center will remain open for up to three months.

Uneasy Journeys
 The routes from Buffalo Avenue to Brooklyn's surviving hospitals do not immediately suggest that St. Mary's former patients will have an easy time making their way to other institutions.
 Kingsbrook, the hospital recommended to St. Mary's patients and the institution that will run its clinics, is probably the closest, 1.3 miles away. For a healthy person, the trip by foot takes about 25 minutes; for a sick person, probably much longer. 
 Even for someone in the best of health, there is no easy way to make the journey by subway. A person would have to take the No. 4 train from the Utica Avenue station, a 10-minute walk from St. Mary's, then transfer at Franklin Avenue for the 2 or 5 train to Winthrop Street, which is another 10-minute walk from Kingsbrook. The bus routes between the two institutions are not much better; a person would have to transfer from the B15 to the B46, which runs along Utica Avenue. 
 The trip to Interfaith Medical Center, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, is slightly easier, a ride north on the B15 bus, which travels a long and busy route between Bedford-Stuyvesant and Kennedy Airport. Yet on that line, according to riders who share their experiences on the Straphangers Campaign online bulletin board, buses rarely arrive on schedule, and stops are sometimes skipped. 
 For Katrina and Harriet McCloud, none of the options look very good, nor does paying a car service $5 to $10 to ferry them to a hospital each time an emergency occurs.
 But they will have to find a way now, as they did a few weeks ago, when Harriet McCloud was taken to New York Methodist Hospital in Park Slope with kidney problems resulting from dialysis. The next morning, exhausted from treatment, she and her daughter found few transportation options back to Crown Heights. 
 Harriet McCloud has announced that distance aside, she just doesn't want to go to another hospital. Her daughter is simply trying to figure out the logistics.
 ''Starting today, the reality is setting in,'' Katrina McCloud said a few days ago. ''No, you do not have a hospital to walk to anymore.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers Details of Plan For Open Markets in China

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: XIANGHE, China, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is expected to present China's political leaders on Sunday with a sweeping plan to overhaul China's financial markets and open the country to foreign banks, investment firms and insurance companies.
 Administration officials say the plan is part of an effort to put the yuan into a broader debate over China's lopsided reliance on exports as the main source of economic growth.
The plan, to be discussed in two days of talks here and in Beijing, calls for China to speed up the privatization of state-owned companies, including banks; to develop a Chicago-style futures market for currency trading; to establish an independent credit-rating agency; and to crack down on bailouts for banks left holding bad loans.
 ''What we tried to do is take a quantum leap in sophistication and scope,'' said Timothy D. Adams, undersecretary for international affairs at the Treasury Department. ''It gives you a picture of the truly complex nature of what we are trying to do.'' 
 Though many of the ideas are familiar, and often supported by Chinese leaders in principle, the list reflects an increased effort to lecture China about internal financial issues. 
 That could backfire. Chinese leaders invariably bristle at pressure from American officials, and they could view the new American ''priorities'' as an unwelcome intrusion.
 The new tack comes as Treasury Secretary John W. Snow continues to show little progress on the volatile economic dispute with China over exchange rates.
 Republican and Democratic lawmakers in Congress have long complained that the yuan has been pegged at an artificially low value against the dollar, making Chinese exports to the United States cheaper than they would otherwise be.
 China announced a 2 percent revaluation in July, but have yet to follow with any additional changes. Based on signals from senior Chinese officials on Friday and Saturday, Mr. Snow is unlikely to return to Washington next week with any evidence of new progress.
 Mr. Snow has been arguing that China needs to get people to spend more and save less. Administration officials say that a financial overhaul would help make that happen.
 Many economists agree with that assessment, but they caution that there are limits to what the United States can do to speed up change.
 ''They are doing a smart thing, because the exchange rate is a small part of the overall economic relationship,'' said Andrew Rothman, a Shanghai-based strategist at CLSA Asia-Pacific, a brokerage firm. But he added, ''This is not the kind of thing where someone flips a switch and it happens overnight.''
 Mr. Rothman said that China had already embraced many of the ideas that Mr. Snow was promoting and that consumer spending has grown sharply in the past few years.
 Retail sales in China have been climbing about 10 percent a year for the past several years, he said. Household credit, virtually nonexistent five years ago, now accounts for 16 percent of all outstanding credit.
 But many of the Bush administration's proposals would encounter fierce political opposition from many quarters.
 China's state-owned banks and far-flung rural credit cooperatives have many defenders in the ruling Communist party, and they are certain to oppose well-financed competition from Western banks. 
 Even without opposition from vested interests, many Chinese leaders are likely to fret over giving more freedom to foreign financial institutions to enter Chinese markets.
 Under current laws, foreign investors are usually prohibited from owning more than 25 percent of a commercial bank, and no single foreign investor can own more than 20 percent.
 According to a document that Treasury officials plan to circulate among Chinese leaders, the Bush administration would remove the limits on foreign ownership as well as a host of other restricitons.
 Foreign financial institutions that want to buy Chinese securities would be freed from having to have at least $10 billion in assets and to have been in business at least five years.
 Foreign-affiliated banks, brokerage firms and insurers would be freed from restrictions on setting up multiple branches at one time.
