HEADLINE: Towers Grow in Downtown Brooklyn

BYLINE: By LISA CHAMBERLAIN

 BODY:
The resurgence of Brooklyn neighborhoods like Park Slope and Williamsburg is well documented. But what is not as widely known is how well the downtown business district is doing, despite a still somewhat dog-eared appearance. What is more, the area is on the verge of a major transformation.
 In the borough's six million square feet of Class A office space -- modern property in highly desirable locations -- the vacancy rate was only 6.8 percent in the third quarter of 2005; brokers say that is one of the lowest rates in the country. The Gallery at Fulton Street, more commonly known as the Fulton Mall, is regarded as a highly successful urban shopping center, commanding annual rents upward of $200 a square foot and drawing 100,000 shoppers a day. There is even a growing residential population in downtown Brooklyn. 
 And all this has occurred before a dizzying array of planned development and beautification projects have begun, although several will soon be formally announced. 
 The core commercial district is roughly bounded by Tillary Street to the north, Flatbush Avenue to the east, Atlantic Avenue to the south and Court Street/Cadman Plaza to the west. 
 During a recent walking tour, Michael Burke -- director of the Downtown Brooklyn Council, a nonprofit economic development corporation charged with promoting as well as coordinating downtown Brooklyn's redevelopment plans -- pointed out sites where about 2,000 new units of housing, 4.5 million square feet of office space and 900,000 square feet of retailing space are under construction or in various stages of planning. 
 Much of this has been spurred by a rezoning of the area that took effect on July 1, 2004, which allows for residential development and provides for denser commercial and mixed-use projects.
 The center of the new commercial core is Willoughby Square, which will be bordered by three large mixed-use towers; two are already in the planning process and a third is still speculative. Willoughby Square itself will be a 1.5-acre park constructed on land that now has old low-rise buildings and parking lots and is being condemned by the city. A large parking garage will be built underneath the park.
 As a result of a deal recently worked out with the city, Thor Equities, a Manhattan-based development company, expects to begin construction within a year on the first new mixed-use tower on Willoughby Square. This 60-story 1.2-million-square-foot tower will sit opposite the proposed park on a 40,000-square-foot lot that now holds a city-owned above-ground parking garage.
 Disclosing details of their plans for the first time in an interview last week, the developers of the Thor Tower said they expected the building to have 100,000 square feet of stores, 100,000 square feet of commercial office space, 400,000 square feet of hotel space (with two hotels, one moderately priced and the other upscale) and 600,000 square feet of condominiums. 
 Thor Equities has not yet secured an anchor tenant for the office space, but has had expressions of interest from several hotel operators. Construction is expected to take 18 months.
 The city is said to be close to designating a developer for the second tower to occupy the Willoughby West site, and an agreement is expected to be announced within a couple of months. The third piece, called Willoughby South, is envisioned for land that is not yet assembled.
 A developer for a fourth tower, to be built west of Willoughby Square on Boerum Place between Livingston and Fulton Streets, is also expected to be announced within a matter of weeks.
 Willoughby Square is a noticeable departure from downtown Brooklyn's first commercial redevelopment project, MetroTech Center, which was started more than 15 years ago when downtown was a much more run-down and dangerous place. MetroTech's buildings were designed to face inward, creating a protected campus. Most of the commercial space there is occupied by people who work in the back-office operations of financial firms. 
 By contrast, Willoughby Square is envisioned as filling a role like that of Bryant Park in Midtown Manhattan, which is open and heavily used by the public even though there are towers around it. This open plan reflects the fact that downtown Brooklyn is now safer and more attractive, and should be attractive to newer, hipper businesses. 
 ''The next wave of commercial activity is going to be a different type of tenant from the usual back office,'' said Glenn Markman, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield, who has been working in and around downtown Brooklyn for the better part of 15 years. ''It's going to be publishing companies, media firms and entertainment companies that recognize that their labor pool lives in Brooklyn now.''
 And that labor pool is not only going to be in adjacent neighborhoods like Cobble Hill and Dumbo (for Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass), but downtown as well. Residential projects under way are clustered on the south end of the commercial district along Schermerhorn Street, Boerum Place and Livingston Street. 
 The city is also set to announce that EDAW, an international landscape design firm, will direct an $8 million streetscaping improvement plan for the Fulton Mall. In addition, $13 million has been designated for the reconstruction and streetscaping of Flatbush and Myrtle Avenues. 
 The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has announced a $162 million renovation of the Jay Street and Lawrence Street subway stations, with an underground tunnel connecting them. 
 And on the edge of the core commercial district is the area where Forest City Ratner has proposed to build a huge mixed-use development that includes a new arena for the New Jersey Nets basketball team.
 ''What's going on in downtown Brooklyn is mind-boggling,'' said Joseph J. Sitt, president and chief executive of Thor Equities. The owner of the Fulton Mall, which opened in 1980, Thor Equities has been making major improvements there, as well as developing two other sites in downtown Brooklyn for a total of roughly two million square feet of commercial and retail space under its control.
 ''People ask if I'm afraid of overinvesting in downtown Brooklyn,'' Mr. Sitt said, ''but I say the timing is perfect.''

HEADLINE: Azerbaijani Leader Confident His Party Will Win

BYLINE: By C.J. CHIVERS

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
President Ilham Aliyev predicted Tuesday that his governing New Azerbaijan Party would post an overwhelming victory in elections next month and said the conditions for a revolution did not exist here.
 Mr. Aliyev's confident prediction came in the final weeks of campaigning for the 125 seats in Parliament, amid growing Western criticism that the government was not ensuring a free and fair electoral process.
 The election is being watched as a sign of whether Mr. Aliyev -- who succeeded his father as president in 2003 after an election that was strongly criticized for fraud, voter intimidation and state manipulation of the tally -- is willing to liberalize his politics and allow alternative voices in public life. 
 The races, pitting the governing party against independent candidates and several small and generally fragmented opposition parties, have been influenced by the popular uprisings since late 2003 that have forced post-Soviet governments from power in Georgia, Ukraine and Kyrgyzstan. 
 Some opposition members here wear orange ties, shirts and scarves, adopting the color of the Orange Revolution in Ukraine. A few have carried posters bearing the face of President Bush and the slogan ''We want freedom too!''
 But the opposition has not been highly visible or able to draw huge crowds, and Mr. Aliyev dismissed its significance in an interview with Western correspondents on Tuesday. ''The opposition seems to be very disorganized, weak,'' he said. ''Their attempts to create a prerevolutionary situation in Azerbaijan failed.''
 Azerbaijan is a post-Soviet republic in an economic boom. Rich in oil and gas, it broke from its former rulers in Moscow and adopted a strategy of collaborating with Western governments and corporations. In a few years, as new pipelines that have been built with Western assistance open, it is projected to begin exporting as much as a million barrels of oil a day.
 Its economy has begun to take off, and a rush of construction is evident here in the capital. The federal budget has expanded and salaries have risen, according to the United Nations Development Program, which reviews Azerbaijan's economic data.
 While 40 percent of the population is living in poverty, the percentage is falling, and a national survey of 1,200 Azerbaijanis, conducted in June by the International Republican Institute and partly underwritten by the United States government, found that 56 percent of those surveyed said the country was headed in the right direction. Thirty-one percent said it was on the wrong track. 
 Mr. Aliyev said that given those economic conditions and signs of optimism, the opposition was unlikely to draw demonstrators to the streets. ''Any similarities with what happened in Georgia and Ukraine are not proper,'' he said, ''and I do not foresee any problem here with respect to the parliamentary election.'' 
 Opposition leaders call his assessments odd, given that security forces have been used to disperse antigovernment rallies, sometimes with force. And for all of his public self-assuredness, Western organizations that are monitoring the elections have warned that the government risks having another tainted vote, undermining its legitimacy.
 Among those urging swift reform is the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe. It recently reported that the government had placed excessive restrictions on freedom of assembly, that media attention had favored government-approved candidates, that voter lists were inaccurate or incomplete and that there had been credible reports of coercion or bribery of voters.
 Opposition leaders say the government's actions belie the president's words. ''How can one call the opposition weak if the authorities are afraid to create equal conditions for the opposition candidates?'' said Ali Kerimli, head of the Popular Front of Azerbaijan, one of three parties that have tried to set aside differences and created a bloc called Azadliq, or Freedom.
 Elman Salayev, a deputy leader of the Azerbaijan Democratic Party, another member of the bloc, said, ''If they think the opposition is weak, then why won't they hold free and fair elections?'' 
 Mr. Salayev said the exiled leader of his party, Rasul Guliyev, who was thwarted Monday in his effort to fly to Azerbaijan and campaign for a parliamentary seat when the government mounted a show of police force near the capital's airport, remained in custody on Tuesday in Ukraine, where his plane landed.
 Mr. Guliyev is wanted on embezzlement and other charges that he says are politically motivated. Mr. Aliyev said Azerbaijan was seeking his extradition, and called him the ''head of an international mafia.''
